PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the federal government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia's Heritage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Australian people have an irreplaceable heritage-built and natural- that is decaying before their eyes.
2. That the 1982-83 Federal Budget is the eighth in a row in which there has been no increase in funding for the preservation of Australia's heritage.

3. That the States and Territories were granted a total of only $2.2 million for an urgent program of works that is awaiting at least $20m to complete and that most of these projects will be in ruins before enough money is available.

4. That there are conservation projects in Queensland alone valued at tens of millions of dollars which have been postponed or abandoned due to lack of funding and that $3 million is needed immediately to complete restoration of properties owned by The National Trust of Queensland.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government approve an urgent supplementary grant of $800,000 for 1982-83, plus a forward commitment for a total allocation of $8 million in the 1983-84 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and

(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDIES OF TERTIARY STUDENT FINANCES-VOLUME 4-EVALUATION OF THE TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE SCHEME

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate has before it volume 4 of a series of reports brought down by a group of authors headed by David Beswick. The papers became available at 11.34 this morning and the one before us is marked as not being available prior to tabling. Therefore I have had three minutes to look at it. I mention that for that reason some of my remarks may have to be brief. The subject of student assistance has been a matter of lively public debate. This report is important because it sets out, in an approach to student financing, what might be called a portfolio approach. The portfolio approach to student assistance, which is recommended and is set out on page 14 of the report, includes a number of components in addition to a system of student loans.

I will read out the components which are identified by the Beswick report in its portfolio approach to student support. They include: Family support, self- help, the provision of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, the provision of loans and the provision of scholarships. I want to make it clear to those honourable senators who might read this report that, far from this report failing to identify loans as an appropriate form of student support as part of a portfolio approach, a document produced in the last week by the Australian Vice- Chancellors' Committee on student finances also identified student loans as one appropriate form of support for students. Against that background it is very sad that the new Australian Labor Party Government has moved to abandon a form of student loans and, contrary to its promises, has failed to put in place any other form of support. Students in Australia are worse off today than they were when the Labor Party took government. At that stage they had TEAS and a system of student loans. Today they do not have the loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think there will be something in the economic statement?
—I am asked whether I think there will be something in the economic statement. I hope so, but I hold no real hopes.
—That does not make sense.

—I am sorry. I would hope so, but I doubt that it will occur . I thank Senator Chipp for correcting me. Student loans were to come into effect for this academic year. During the election period no steps were taken by the Department to process the fine details. But in spite of this between 700 and 800 students actually made applications for student loans under the scheme. This figure was given to us last week in Estimates Committee D by Mr Rolfe, one of the officers. In spite of the fact that there were difficulties 700 to 800 students found it possible to make applications to receive student loans. They have now been disappointed. Loans have not been introduced because the Government has an ideological commitment against them.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Government, when it is considering this report, what the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee put and what students need, to be eclectic and flexible in its approach and to look again at areas where the loans have some part to play. The Government has promised, as a sop, to put more money into the institutional emergency loans schemes. It is my hope that it honours that promise and that, by so doing gives students some chance to benefit. It is desirable that we look at this question of tertiary student finances in the hope that certain other senators too may be able to take part in the discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this discussion because Senator Peter Baume has subjected the Government to castigation and reprimand for in fact implementing, as speedily as it did, the wishes of the population most directly affected by the Government's proposal that a students loans scheme be put in place. The body representing Australian students in tertiary institutions throughout Australia most strenuously opposed the introduction of a loans scheme . Senator Baume described the alternative-namely, putting funds into the institutional emergency arrangements within our tertiary institutions-as a mere sop. The fact is that that is the most desirable course.

SPEECH.PARA: I can say from my own experience at the University of Tasmania-it is shared by all those who have had anything to do with our colleges or university institutions-that tertiary institutions have administered student schemes most efficiently, most compassionately and with a good understanding of the needs of the students studying in these institutions, particularly their needs for funds not only to secure their immediately narrowly conceived educational requirements , but also to cover housing and social activities which are part of their natural life as students within an institution. Those matters are best understood by the educational institutions involved. I believe that the arrangements within those institutions for making loans available to students at reduced interest rates have proved to be a reasonable way in which to operate.

Of course there is nothing to stop individual banks such as the Commonwealth Bank from making loans available to students should they approach such banking institutions. But it is notorious that in the United States the banks lobbied against the continuation of such schemes in the Californian tertiary education system. They found that with the highly mobile population in the United States of America-this is the case in Australia also-very often loans which were taken up by students were not repaid by them when they moved to other States and Territories. In fact, it could be left to the Australian Government to pick up the tab for defaulting borrowers. It would still be within the discretion of the bank, under the Government's previous loans scheme, whether a loan was granted or not. One might well ask how a bank or manager would determine whether a loan ought to be granted when a prospective student came for a conference with him. He may consider the student's socio-economic background and whether it was likely that he would go through the course and obtain the qualification which would perhaps enable him, if he were lucky enough to secure employment and earn the funds necessary, to repay the loan. If the bank manager made a judgment that the person might not be successful in completing his course and gaining a degree , the loan might not be available anyway. I think the Government is to be commended for moving as quickly as it did to say that the community-I know Senator Macklin is most interested in this concept-is making a proper investment in the future of Australia by ensuring that adequate funds are available to enable our students to undertake tertiary studies and that it ought not to be a question of whether one can secure a loan from a banking organisation which should determine one's access to higher education.

This Government believes that Australia's future will be better secured if we have as many students as possible participating in tertiary studies and being retained within those tertiary institutions. I notice that the report tabled this morning contains chapters dealing with case studies of attrition due to lack of family support, distance from home, need for independence, ineligibility for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and so on. I say that it would be better for honourable senators opposite to spend time analysing those chapters than for them to castigate the Government for doing away with the tertiary loans scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the fourth volume of the Study of Tertiary Student Finances. The three other volumes in relation to the Study of Tertiary Student Finances have been debated previously in the Senate with some interest. In fact, I studied this volume hoping to see that note had been taken of the points I raised previously, particularly in relation to what I saw as flawed methods of research in the previous volumes, and whether they had been picked up. The point at issue to which the two honourable senators who spoke previously addressed themselves is, in fact, only a very small part of this volume which deals with student loans. I think the discussion in this report takes place merely on the basis of whether there will be mandatory loans, whether we are looking at discretionary loans being made through the institutions or at some other forms of finance. I think the points made in the report were covered fairly extensively in the debate last year in relation to this item. I do not really feel there is a need for them to be rehearsed.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope the Government will address itself to the details contained in this report about the disincentive to undertake tertiary education on the part of a variety of people within our community, particularly those from lower socio- economic groupings. But it is stretching one's imagination to the utmost to believe that the distribution of intelligence in our community ties in totally with the distribution of wealth. Unfortunately, when one looks at the people who are able to go to tertiary institutions that is, indeed, what one finds-that there is an inverse proportion in the number of people in higher socio-economic groupings compared with people from other income brackets. What the current Government has upon its plate which was not addressed by the previous Government in any marked way is the need to try to redress that imbalance. It should be trying to enable people who have the capacity, the understanding and the will to go into tertiary institutions regardless of their socio-economic backgrounds. Unless we do that we are effectively organising for ourselves in this country the denial to future generations of the worth of those people and their input in all areas of study regardless of whether those areas be scientific, technological or artistic. I believe we must make sure that we are providing schemes of student finance which will enable that to take place.

One area which I believe is vitally important-these studies have tended to look at undergraduates particularly-is the area of post-graduate studies. In this area I have advocated that if a person actually has the capacity to undertake and has undertaken successfully undergraduate studies, every one of those people ought to be permitted to undertake secondary or higher degrees. This was why the Australian Democrats in particular had such vehement objection to the imposition of fees at that level. We believe that it is at that level that one gets maximum return, not marginal return, for every dollar spent. So in those areas we believe there needs to be an open-ended commitment on the part of the Government to allow all those people who have the capacity and who have completed a primary degree to be able to undertake a second degree within our current tertiary institutions. Finally, if we have a detailed debate on this matter at a later stage-I believe that honourable senators will so move-we might be able to concentrate on some of the other areas, particularly on the characteristics of the people who are currently being denied access to tertiary institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that the fourth volume of the Studies of Tertiary Student Finances has been raised in the several brief speeches in the Senate this morning. The fourth volume report is very important to the Senate. It follows on from the public inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts into the student loans scheme which was the former Government's proposal. SPEECH.PARA: The whole of the four volumes of the report which is now before us needs to be debated. Because that loans scheme has been terminated by the new Government we are now discussing an area which does not have adequate financial provision for tertiary students in Australia. I believe that it is right for Senator Peter Baume, in commenting on this report, to regret not only on his behalf but also on the behalf of many honourable senators in this chamber that that is the current state of affairs in Australia. The new Government has denied financial resources to tertiary students without giving any specific outline of the scheme that it hopes will come to pass during the term of this Parliament. Therefore I take issue with Senator Tate when he says that the Government should be commended in the present instance for withdrawing that scheme. I do not believe that that is something that we on this side of the chamber can assent to. I do not believe that the Government can be commended for withdrawing that loans scheme money from hundreds of students who had applied for it. They will now be denied the financial resources to undertake studies this year. How many students have been denied access to tertiary studies in 1983 because of the decisions of this Government? The report that is before the Senate brings home to us the importance of that whole area. No, there are no specific comprehensive inquiries at the CAEs and universities with regard to the needs for that emergency loans scheme given that this Government has denied the loan scheme that was available this year'. So the unfinished question on that grant is also a matter that comes out of this four-volume study. Quite contrary to what Senator Tate said I do not believe that this is an occasion to commend the Government. I believe that we in the Senate should take full cognisance of the report of the bipartisan Senate Standing Committee which thoroughly investigated these matters and which saw room for that loans scheme within the full spectrum of tertiary education finances in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take very much time of the Senate at this stage but I feel I must make some comments on the wild misinformation that Senator Teague has delivered to us and repeat some of the very sound and accurate analyses made by Senator Tate when he commented on the decision of the Government not to proceed with the student loans scheme which was a proposal of the previous Government. A couple of points need to be made very strongly. First of all, no student organisation supported the loans scheme. It was seen by students, as it was by the Australian Labor Party, as a scheme which would benefit only those students from affluent, secure backgrounds who would be in a position to negotiate loans. I think Senator Tate made it quite clear. I know there was support from the Australian Democrats when he said that we do not consider one's financial ability to negotiate a loan as a suitable criterion for entrance into tertiary education.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point to be made is that the Labor Party in Opposition made it quite clear from the moment the previous Government started to talk about this scheme that we would not proceed with it. We were supported in that view by all student organisations. There can be no question of deception or misleading of students. It is true that a number of students made application under the loans scheme that the previous Government introduced. It is also true that not one of those loans was concluded. There was no loans scheme in operation. No loans have been negotiated, and the reason why the loans have not been negotiated is that the complications were so enormous, and the unsuitability of the scheme was evident right from the very outset. It is the intention of this Government to increase the level of student assistance, and that will be a matter for Budget announcement. But we remain firm in our view that the kind of loans scheme proposed by the former Government was, as might be expected, a scheme to assist students from affluent middle class families, a scheme which would have deterred able students from entering into tertiary studies. Our aim is quite opposite to that.

Senator Teague also said some very misleading things about my comments on the emergency loans scheme. It is the case that all universities have a small amount of money, which was granted to them under the Whitlam Administration, to make emergency loans to students in a variety of crisis situations. The emergency loans scheme was not set up to provide ongoing financial support for students through all their graduate or under-graduate studies. It is not a suitable replacement for the proper level of income support for students that this Government intends to provide. Nor is it an appropriate replacement for those loans which were sought by some students. I suppose some students thought that the Fraser Government might be returned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just another promise.

—There was no promise. The promise made by Labor in Opposition was that we would cancel this inequitable, impractical scheme immediately, and we have fulfilled that promise. We also promised to undertake a series of measures to assist students of ability and motivation from all backgrounds to enter tertiary education, and we are currently engaged in negotiating those schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: The emergency loan scheme is a separate matter. It is not true, as Senator Teague said, that I reported to the Senate Estimates Committee that I would, in my own good time, look into this scheme. It is true, as I reported to the Senate Estimates Committee, that I have asked the Tertiary Education Commission to report to me on the state of those emergency loan funds. I should make it clear that we do not see those emergency loan funds as having any purpose other than assisting students in an emergency situation. A student from an affluent family, doing a three-year or four-year course of study, is not an appropriate person to be assisted. So I do not want to raise any false hopes of those students who were prepared to take out loans under the previous Government's scheme that the emergency loans scheme will be a replacement. It will not. What will happen is that there will be an increase in the general level of support for students who need it and there will be, as a result, a greatly increased participation in tertiary studies.

—Mr President, I have finished my answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Are we to assume from the Minister's answer to that part of my question which he attempted to answer that not only is he prepared to try to control the export of minerals from this country, but also he is out to control the production of minerals in this country?
—I pointed out the simple fact that the Federal Government has absolute control over everything that is exported from or imported in to this country, if it chooses to exercise that control.
—Subject to parliament.
—Of course.
—Senator Walsh, will you answer the supplementary question?

—Governments, in varying degrees ever since there has been a Federal government, have exercised that control. It will be exercised responsibly by this Government and in the interests of the Australian people.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, in her capacity as Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of the recently announced progress of the South Australian Co-ordinated Committee Against Sexual Harassment towards a clear and legally accepted definition of such abuse in South Australia? Is the Federal Government monitoring reforms being introduced by State Australian Labor Party governments in the area of combating sexual harassment? Can the community look forward to the adoption of measures at a federal level similar to those reforms currently being examined in South Australia, such as the legal definition of sexual harassment and the drawing up of complaint procedures within government departments, including educational institutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question touches on a matter which is of growing concern in the work force. The incidence-or the reported incidence-of sexual harassment is increasing every day. There is no doubt that the record level of unemployment which, of course, is even higher for women, has exacerbated a very unsavoury situation for many women employees, who are placed in a much more vulnerable position with regard to this kind of violation of their rights than they would be in a situation of full employment in which they could, with confidence, leave a job where they were being harassed in this way and take another one. The Government takes very seriously the reports of this kind of violation of the rights of women workers. Consequently, in reply to the specific part of the honourable senator's question, we are monitoring the progress that is being made in the various Labor States with regard to the development of legislative and administrative machinery to protect women against sexual harassment in the work place.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to our intentions federally, the Government will introduce sex discrimination legislation in this session. That legislation will provide some measure of protection against sexual harrassment in the areas of employment which it covers. It will cover all areas of Commonwealth employment-statutory bodies and so forth-and areas of large private employment. We will be building on and strengthening the efforts being made in the States to provide legislative and other forms of protection against this most unacceptable form of intrusion on the rights of working women.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, relates to the announced intention of the Government to impose a resource rent tax. In a number of statements the Minister has suggested that such a tax would be imposed only if the States agreed to it. I refer the Minister to the answer he gave to a question asked by Senator Maguire on 5 May when he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if the States do not co-operate I do not believe that there is very much we can do.
That statement echoes the report of an interview in the Bulletin on 3 May, when he was reported to have said:
With oil we can do almost anything we like. With everything else, if the States do not co-operate, there is nothing much we can do, anyway.

In contrast to that there were statements by his predecessor, Mr Keating. I instance one of them. Mr Keating referred to the power that the Government would have to remove the incentives for State mineral taxation by re-arranging Commonwealth-State finances, and he said:
In simple terms, this would involve reducing Commonwealth general revenue grants to individual States by the amount in question.

So, there was a suggestion of possible coercion in the statement of Mr Keating last year. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether it is a firm Government decision that a resource rent tax will be introduced only if there is agreement with those States which are affected by the imposition of such a tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am sure Senator Chaney appreciates very well, the situation is that the primary taxing right, excise excluded, for minerals located on-shore rests with the States; and the comments that I have been making about that are based upon the recognition of that simple fact. But there is certainly no legal impediment to the Commonwealth imposing a resource rent tax additional to the various taxes already imposed by the States. However, it is not the objective of the Government to impose an additional tax because, firstly, at least at this stage, few mining enterprises, if any, are in a position in the long term- indefinitely anyway-to pay an additional tax and, secondly, our intention is not that there be a new or additional tax but that there be a replacement tax for those which are already in existence.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the comments that Mr Keating made-again inevitably I am relying upon my recollections of what Senator Chaney said-my interpretation of the passage quoted by Senator Chaney is that if a State agrees to surrender whatever taxing right it now has, then obviously some offsetting financial arrangements will have to be made through the distribution of general purpose payments to the States. I am not in a position to say whether it is legally feasible to introduce an arrangement whereby the States themselves levy a rent-type tax on the mining industries. If that were legally possible, in my view that would be a satisfactory alternative to a federal tax. But I suspect that the legal situation is such that only the Commonwealth Government could collect the type of tax preferred by the present Federal Government, although that, of course, would not preclude revenue gained from within a State by such a tax collected by the Commonwealth Government being returned to that State. If that were done the bottom line regarding revenue to all the States is ultimately determined, under existing arrangements anyway, by the absolute size of Commonwealth payments to the States and the distribution of that absolute payment among the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen an article on the front page of this week's Tasmanian Mail headed 'Welfare cheats warned'? Is he one of the welfare cheats concerned and what is his reaction to his warning? Can he inform the Senate whether social security fraud is a major problem in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to the article on the front page of the Tasmanian Mail and no, I am not one of the welfare cheats talked about in the article. This article is the third in a series produced in the Tasmanian Mail. The first was an alleged letter from a reader complaining about what were described as social security cheats. The next article consisted of a series of responses to that letter, raising the matter of what those readers or the writers of those letters described as the problem of social security cheats in Tasmania. The final article, which appeared this week, as Senator Coates says, is headlined 'Welfare Cheats Warned' and contains a photograph of me, reference to the Tasmanian Mail approaching me in Canberra and asking my view, and comments from officers of the Department of Social Security in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: I say first of all that I think the tone of this article and the other articles is unfortunate and gives a very unbalanced picture. The simple fact is that social security fraud-by 'fraud', I mean people who cheat on the system deliberately-is not a problem in Tasmania. In fact, in the totality of the social security budget, it is not a problem in this country at all. Of course it occurs and, of course, this Government, like other governments, does not approve of it and will seek to eliminate it as much as possible. I am talking about deliberate fraud and cheating on the system, such as people who receive multiple benefits illegally, or who work and receive an income and at the same time are receiving benefits and not declaring that income. This Government does not approve of that sort of behaviour at all. But this article, like the ones before it, implies that the social security system is in fact burdened by people such as that.

What disturbs me is the tone and the lack of balance in the article, but two aspects particularly disturb me. One is that the article encourages people to ring the Department of Social Security or, apparently, my office, anonymously, and report people. The article encourages this behaviour, the implication being that I encourage it. I do not believe it is appropriate in our society for people to ring making anonymous accusations against others on the scale that has followed the publication of this article. I do not believe that is the sort of society we want, or want to encourage.
The second point about this article is that it says:
The Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, has been approached in Canberra over the numerous complaints.
He is treating the subject matter seriously and is understood to have asked the Department in Tasmania to treat the matter with priority.

What is disturbing about that report is that at no time did the Tasmanian Mail approach me. At no time was I asked to comment on the previous articles, nor have I made comment on them. If I had had the opportunity to do so, I hope I would have been able to introduce some balance into the article. I think it is unfortunate when newspapers claim that they are representing the views of the Minister and have contacted the Minister when they have not. I think it is particularly unfortunate when reporters from those newspapers approach officers of my Department telling them that they have approached me when in fact they have not.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware that a condition of the house arrest of Father Brian Gore in the Philippines on what is probably a trumped up murder charge is that Father Gore must not give interviews to the media, which means that Father Gore is now in a position where he cannot speak publicly on his own behalf? Is the Minister aware of statements made by Father Gore on the Australian Broadcasting Commission AM program on Monday, which may well have been the last interview he could give, of the extraordinary circumstances of his arrest in which interview he pointed out that soldiers:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . came in a gunship-helicopter and came across, jumped out of the gunship with guns . . .
Father Gore said that he would not go with them in the helicopters, that he would not, 'go in the things', and that they would go down later. He said:

We followed them down about 20-30 minutes later and we were met by a convoy of two jeeps full of soldiers who surrounded us, with balaclavas and masks, and I thought it was it, I thought we were going to be ambushed.
Father Gore's final comment was:
It was an over . . . maybe an overkill tactic of trying to scare us.

Is the Minister aware that this week the Philippines Government has created new laws under which journalists can be imprisoned for life or sentenced to death for criticism of the Government? In view of these gross civil rights infringements, and especially the position of a respected Australian citizen, Father Brian Gore, will the Government express Australia's repugnance to the Philippines at civil rights violations in that country? Will the Government reconsider the extent of Australian assistance to the Philippines, especially with regard to the military aid we are giving in this financial year, which I understand totals $1.848m, mostly in the form of staff exchanges, training and assistance programs and Nomad aircraft maintenance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information available to the Government about Father Brian Gore can be summarised at present as follows: He was arrested on a murder charge on 6 May, together with Father O'Brien, an Irish priest, Father Dangan, a Filipino priest, and six lay workers. President Marcos ordered the release of the three priests under house arrest on 7 May. The six lay workers have not been released.

ANSWER.PARA: Bail petitions were lodged on 10 May. At the bail hearing on 17 May Father Gore and the other priests were formally arraigned on the charge of multiple murder, all pleading not guilty. Three of the other six people who were also charged and who were recently arrested turned state's evidence and were removed from the charge sheet. The proceedings were then adjourned to today-Wednesday, 18 May- with Father Gore, Father O'Brien and Father Dangan remaining under house arrest.
We do not have precise details as to the conditions of those arrests, except the general advice is that the conditions are in fact quite lenient.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can take it that that is definite; he is not allowed to speak to the media.
—We do not have definite confirmation that the non-access to the media is a condition of Father Gore's house arrest although that confirmation is being sought at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case, of course, as the honourable senator indicated in his question, that Bob Wurth of the Australian Broadcasting Commission interviewed Father Gore in Negros after he had been released into house arrest, that interview being broadcast on 9 May. Whether that is the last such media interview that will be allowed I am not yet in a position to be able to advise the honourable senator.

The only other matters I add are these: Such available information as we have about the conduct of the case generally indicates that due processes of law are being properly applied. The Australian Consul in Manila visited Father Gore at his residence in Oringao on 9 May. Father Gore then indicated that he had no request for additional assistance. The Consul is presently in Kabankalan for the bail hearing.
Mr Hayden, of course, met Father Gore in Manila and was assured of his satisfaction with the present level of Australian interest and concern about his case.

As to the final, more general, matter that Senator Mason raised, the situation is that the Government has publicly indicated that it will take a heightened interest in human rights issues and will certainly take this into account in its foreign policy making. This interest has certainly been registered with and is well known to the Philippine authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General have any evidence that Australian companies trading overseas are falling foul of American anti-trust legislation? Is the Attorney-General of the opinion that the agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the United States of America relating to co- operation on anti-trust matters signed last June offers enough protection for Australian companies trading overseas? If the answer to the second part of the question is no, does the Attorney-General have any intention of introducing legislation, such as the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement ) Amendment Bill 1981 to allow protection for Australian companies in the future ? Does the Attorney-General intend to have the matter of anti-trust agreements on the agenda of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with a view to arriving at a broader treaty agreeable to all trading nations?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is aware that several Australian companies and/or their overseas subsidiaries that either operate in the international market-place or carry on business in the United States of America are subject to investigation by United States authorities in connection with the possible violation of United States anti-trust laws. I am not at liberty to disclose the names of those companies because the information has been passed to the Australian Government on a confidential basis.

QUESTION.PARA: The Australian Government is also aware, of course, of the current anti-trust investigation which commenced in May 1980 by the United States Department of Justice in relation to the Australian-United States ocean shipping trade. Officials from my Department, together with officers from other interested departments, have been monitoring the progress of these investigations to ensure that Australia's national interest is protected. Some recent developments in that respect are causing us some concern.

As to the parts of the question relating to the bilateral agreement with the United States and the possible future of the recovery Bill, the situation is this: Since taking office the present Government has not made any formal decisions yet, as a government, about either the bilateral agreement or the need for further legislation, such as the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Amendment Bill 1981 which was introduced by my predecessor, Senator Durack. In Opposition we did express general support for both these measures. I simply advise that, in accordance with my instructions, my Department has already begun consultations with other departments on these questions. When those consultations have been completed I do intend bringing the matter forward to Cabinet. I can also say that I am planning to visit the United Kingdom and the United States late next month in order to discuss, along with two or three other matters of importance, these and related questions on extra-territoriality .

As to the final part of the question relating to the OECD, the situation is that Australia has already made a detailed statement in January this year on the bilateral agreement with the United States to Working Party 3 of the OECD's Restrictive Business Practices Committee. I understand that that agreement has generated considerable interest among other countries. There is probably a general consensus that both multilateral and bilateral agreements or understandings of this kind are a useful means by which jurisdictional conflicts between nations can be avoided or resolved in a spirit consistent with that generally attempted by the present Government of accommodation and compromise according to the principles of comity and national sovereignty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the Senate of the cost to the national economy, in particular to the community of the Hunter River region, of the seven-month-old strike at Drayton mine in New South Wales? Further, can the Minister explain to the Senate and people of Australia how it is that this Government of so-called consensus cannot resolve this more and more serious confrontation in our community?

—I am only able to say that I thought I saw some reports of some possible solution to the dispute involving the Drayton mine. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and obtain an answer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of reports that the surface of the Tindal airstrip caused problems during the recent defence exercise code-named Pitch Black? If so, can the Minister give details of the problems? Can he also indicate when the committee which was recently formed to investigate the development of Tindal and comprising Commonwealth, Northern Territory and local government officials expects to hand down its report?

—I am afraid I have to confess that in the rush of recent events the condition of the surface of the Tindal airstrip escaped my notice. But I will in fact draw that question to the attention of the Minister for Defence and secure an early answer for the honourable senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the decision by the Foreign Minister to appoint a committee headed by Mr Gordon Jackson to review Australia's foreign development aid program. I ask: Firstly, why is it that the review committee is composed exclusively of businessmen and economists and totally excludes non- government organisations and others vitally concerned with the delivery of aid? Secondly, what consultation took place before the appointment of the review panel? Thirdly, does the Government repudiate the views expressed on 25 April by the Sydney Morning Herald, which newspaper originally had a representative on the review panel, which rejected the Foreign Minister's statement that the Government is particularly concerned that Australian aid should be employed for the benefit of those people in recipient countries who most need it and insisted that 'it will be wrong if it gives the review a bias towards humanitarian objectives and away from the politics of aid'? Fourthly, how will the Government ensure, in view of the composition of the committee, that the review will uphold the objectives stressed by the Government giving primacy to the maintenance of humanitarian objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aid review panel was appointed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and will provide its report to him. I am advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs that those members were chosen because of the broad range of experiences and skills which they can contribute to such a task. These skills cover much more than economic expertise and business acumen. Their skills cover the full ambit of humanitarian and socio-economic concerns of Third World countries and of program management. It was the Foreign Minister's particular express desire that members of the panel should not be seen to be representing particular sectional interests. For example, the panel will have to examine the role of non-government organisations within the official aid program. Therefore, it was perceived as being inappropriate for a current office holder in a non- government organisation to be included on the panel. Of course, the honourable senators will appreciate that several members of the panel have had very extensive experience in the past in relation to those aid organisations. The panel will be seeking ideas and submissions throughout the whole community.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the general philosophy of aid and the reference the honourable senator made to the Sydney Morning Herald editorial, may I say that the Government accepts that humanitarian concerns are a quite fundamental consideration in framing aid policies. Obviously, other factors, including foreign policy considerations, are also important. One of the tasks of the panel is to ensure that our aid reflects Australia's interests and values while making a real contribution to the economic and social advancement of the people, especially the poorest peoples, in recipient countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Did the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister for Finance issue a statement on 29 March of this year to the effect that in the May sittings of this Parliament the Government intends to introduce legislation to amend the taxation incentive for films provided under Division 10BA of the Commonwealth Income Tax Assessment Act in order to eliminate the bunching of film production? Are these amendments to be introduced during this period of sittings? Are the Ministers aware of the serious effects on the film production industry which would result from failure to ensure passage of the amendments in this period of sittings and the employment implications for those affected?

—The Government's commitment to assisting the film industry in the way outlined by Senator Childs in his question concerning the tax incentives is firm and unwaivering. The legislative provisions will eliminate the bunching that was one of the enormous problems besetting the film industry during the period of the Fraser Administration. I understand that there is bipartisan support for this legislation. It will be proceeded with very quickly and the film industry will have a secure and stable base for future development, which this Government is committed to establish.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it not true that last Saturday, Sunday and Monday Mr Bowen, the Deputy Prime Minister, was the Acting Foreign Minister in this country and that in this capacity he set forth his views concerning Australian and Japanese troops going to Kampuchea? Why should not the Australian public and the world at large expect that these views are the views of the Australian Government? Has the Prime Minister repudiated, reprimanded and disciplined this Minister for abusing his authority both as Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Foreign Minister? In any event, how are we all to know when a Minister of this Government is speaking responsibly or merely putting his feet in his mouth?
—Senator Teague, let me say that if a question is asked in that spirit I will put my foot in your mouth.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr President. Let me say that yes, last Saturday, Sunday and Monday Mr Bowen was the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Yes, he expressed certain views about Japanese and Australian troops participating in a peacekeeping operation in Kampuchea. I understand that his remarks were made at a rural conference in New South Wales. I say to the honourable senator that at the moment I cannot remember the name of the town. I take it that the remarks were made in the context of addressing a party conference and discussing a wide range of solutions which this Government might be able to put forward in relation to a problem about which it is concerned. The comments made by Mr Bowen are no different from the sorts of comments which have been made, for example, by leaders of the National Party at National Party conferences over many years and which were not necessarily in accord with Government policy when the Fraser Government was in office. I do not know whether Mr Bowen has been repudiated, reprimanded and rebuked by--
—And disciplined.

—And disciplined by the Prime Minister. I am unable to answer that question. I have no doubt that the Prime Minister had a friendly discussion with Mr Bowen regarding the matters to which the honourable senator refers.

—Mr President, still having my teeth and tongue in my mouth, I ask a supplementary question. If the Prime Minister has not disciplined the Deputy Prime Minister will he do so, and will he convey an answer to the Senate?

—The supplementary question, of course, repeats the initial value judgment of Senator Teague. I am not going to embark on a process, at Senator Teague's request, of disciplining the Prime Minister to discipline Mr Bowen and so on. If the honourable senator requires a further answer on the matter I can pursue it and give it to him.
—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that organisations funded under the Youth Services Scheme will run out of funds on 30 June? Does the Government propose to continue funding youth refuges?

—I am aware of the situation. Last year the previous Government provided $1.7m, I think, for a one-year continuation of the Youth Services Scheme while a national evaluation was being held. That national evaluation report is available. It has been with the States since April and was made public earlier this month. At the request of Senator Messner I will have it tabled in the Senate next week, the reason for the delay being the need to get sufficient copies. In the meantime I will be consulting with the States as to the continuation of this Scheme. We are continuing the Scheme while also considering the matter of crisis accommodation for youth. I expect that next week, when the report is tabled in the Parliament, we will have some debate on this matter, if I can anticipate Senator Messner's comments from what was said in the Estimates committee last week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance and refers to the bank accounts debits tax. I remind the Minister that when he was in Opposition he described this tax as being inequitable, discriminatory, inflationary and counter-productive. Is it not a fact that the Bank Account Debits Tax Act exempts debits made to accounts in the name of non-profit schools but this exemption does not extend to support bodies associated with the schools? Is this not a tax on the efforts of such organisations as parents and friends organisations which are designed to provide educational aids for the schools which are exempt under the Act? If so, what does the Government intend to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance announced, I think on 29 March, that a review of the application of this tax would take place in six months' time. I am not sure whether Senator Harradine was quoting me when he mentioned that point. Anyway, comments were made by members of the then Opposition about this tax when it was introduced last year. I do not remember saying that, but I recall some people in the then Opposition making those sorts of comments.
—It was a resolution which I supported at that time, and you proposed it.

—Those are the sorts of comments one makes when one has no knowledge of the enormous $10 billion impending deficit. On the Monday after the election, this Government discovered that it faced that deficit, having been told many times in the weeks before by the then Government that the impending deficit was $6 billion. What was the then Government still saying in the week leading up to the election, after it had been twice told by the Department of the Treasury that the impending deficit was between $9 billion and $10 billion? The then Government-the discredited Fraser Liberal-National Party Government-was still telling the Australian Labor Party and the public that the impending deficit was $6 billion, even though it had been twice told by the Treasury that it would be between $9 billion and $10 billion. Since the election, we know the truth-no thanks, of course, to any member of the previous Government. Once the Labor Party assumed government, the Treasury provided to the Labor Party the information which it had previously provided to the discredited Fraser Government.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that $10 billion impending deficit, many actions will have to be taken which would not have been contemplated by the Labor Party at a time when it did not know that it was confronted with that sort of deficit. That will necessarily be one of the questions which will have to be considered when the review forecast by the Minister for Finance takes place in September or thereabouts. As to the finer details of the actual application of this tax to which Senator Harradine referred, I am not able to answer off the cuff and I will refer them to the Minister for Finance for a definitive answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED FIXING OF RESULTS OF FOOTBALL MATCHES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen statements by Mr Meagher, senior counsel assisting the Costigan Royal Commission, that some New South Wales Rugby Football League matches in Sydney and Victorian Football League matches in Melbourne involved teams deliberately controlling the extent of the winning margin? I ask whether he is also aware of a statement by a former captain of the Australian rugby league team, Bob Fulton, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: It's just a ridiculous claim made without one shred of evidence . . . It's the same as the rugby league players association making unsubstantiated allegations about QCs 'fixing' cases in court. I cannot believe people are allowed to make irresponsible and untrue statements without proof.

Is the Attorney-General aware that one of the allegations assumes that on a given day the majority of players in all teams taking part in a round of the New South Wales Rugby League or the VFL were involved in fixing the matches? Does he not agree that this suggestion is ludicrous?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to all those questions is yes. In saying that, I think it ought to be appreciated that the attention that the Press has given this matter really does represent something in the nature of a classic beat-up, as might be expected when the issues of crime and sport are intertwined. The matter lacks only sex in order to occupy all the pages of the newspaper. The particular passages in the Meagher papers which he presented to the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress do not justify, in my view, the degree of speculation and excitement which has in fact been generated. The only reference that I can find to football fixes appears on page 33 of what is a 200-odd page document. In the context of a much longer discussion on the extent of starting price bookmaking and its connection with organised crime, the following passage appears:

ANSWER.PARA: Evidence is now starting to emerge that the bookmakers have extended the events upon which they will accept wagers beyond horse racing to other forms of racing.
There is a reference to dog racing, and then a further sentence which reads:
More recently, however, it appears that football, in the form of Rugby League in Sydney and Australian Rules in Melbourne, has been the subject of wagering.

There is no reference to which particular league he is talking about, whether it is the Victorian Football League in Melbourne or the equivalent organisation in Sydney. It is just a description of the code in question. He then goes on:
This would suggest that organised crime in Australia is moving in accord with organised crime in the United States.
There is then a further discussion on the situation in the United States, in respect of which the following passage appears:

Money is also accepted on the size of the win, this apparently being more frequent than merely upon who may win. Games are 'fixed' by having key players ' shave points'. That is their play will reflect the need to keep the score within the point spread.
Then the following sentence appears:
It is too early to say whether this has come to Australia in a major way although recent reports have suggested that some attempt has been made to fix results in some games.

That is the sole extent of the reference to football in this entire series of papers. I make it clear that the Meagher papers involved Mr Douglas Meagher, Q.C ., speaking for himself and not on behalf of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. That is made perfectly clear in the context of the presentation of these papers. No report of the Commission has been made to date on the subject of SP bookmaking as it affects wagering on matters other than horse racing, nor to my knowledge is any such report, by the Commission as such, contemplated.

Further, it is not clear whether the reports of fixing to which Mr Meagher refers are based in any way on hard evidence or constitute hard evidence available to the Commission or Mr Meagher, or whether they are merely scuttle- butt being retailed. I suggest that in the absence of any hard evidence on this matter, given the considerations to which Senator Sibraa has referred in his question, it would be wise to treat this matter as being in the latter category.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . I refer to two projects which were part of the previous Government's $640m water resource development plans over the next five years. The two projects were the funding of the Split Rock Dam on the Manilla River in New South Wales and the funding necessary to increase the height of the wall of the Glenbawn Dam on the Hunter River. I ask the Minister: Is it the Government's intention to pursue these important water conservation objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall it, the two specific proposals referred to by Senator Scott were included in what was called the supplementary program which the then Prime Minister announced on 25 January. On Thursday night an announcement will be made encompassing this matter, among many others. In the period since the Australian Labor Party was elected to Government, I have made several comments about this supplementary program in general.

ANSWER.PARA: The supplementary program, to cost $350m, was literally pulled out of the hat and, in some cases, out of dusty bottom drawers. Every ill-considered and uneconomic project submitted to the Department for many years was, on the instructions of the former Government, pulled out of bottom drawers and thrown together, on two days' notice, into what was called a supplementary water resources program. It is a prime example of the sort of fiscal irresponsibility which has landed this country into its present mess. It is a major demonstration of the sort of fiscal irresponsibility which caused the previous Government to leave the present Government with the dreadful legacy of an impending deficit approaching $10 billion.

The circumstances under which this program was announced should be recalled. The then Prime Minister was desperately seeking an excuse to have a premature election before the public found out the truth about the state of the economy and the condition of Government finances. As part of that campaign to set the scene for a premature election which he cynically thought he could win-so he was a fool as well as a knave-he produced out of the hat this supplementary water resources program. In most cases there was no economic evaluation and in most of the other cases where there was an economic evaluation it was highly adverse. One case involved a project which the State Government-I emphasise, the State Government-had already stopped. But none of those considerations of responsibility or fair dealing mattered to the then Prime Minister at that time, because he was obsessed with having an early election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And his colleagues.

—Yes, and his colleagues. They knew about it. The Treasurer of the day knew the broad order of magnitude of what was coming up, and he is the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party today. The then Prime Minister and his colleagues knew what was coming up. They decided that they would set the scene for an early election. Part of the superficially attractive backdrop to the scene for that election was this supplementary water resources program. Had the previous Government been re-elected, of course, that backdrop would very quickly have been dropped. The Fraser Government, had it survived the election, would have repudiated that promise and dozens of other promises which it had previously made. But it hoped that prior to the election that it planned it could raise expectations, do a bit of a fiscal conjuring trick and generate some illusions, one of which was this program. As to the specifics of the question, I am afraid Senator Scott will have to wait until the statement is made on Thursday night.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the current uncertainty in regard to the funding of women's refuges and rape crisis centres, particularly in States such as Queensland where continuation of these facilities is dependent on fund raising? Can the Minister outline this Government's policy in regard to stabilising and rationalising funding of women' s services centres so that Australian women may have confidence in the future of these vitally important programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Reynolds said, there has been considerable uncertainty in the area of women's emergency programs in the last few years. For this reason the present Government intends to introduce a national women's emergency services program. We have a specific interest in this area because, for instance , the women's shelters were first funded federally by an Australian Labor Party Government. If ever a program demonstrated a previously unfulfilled need that program did. Up until 1981 the Commonwealth's direct involvement in the funding was very important to the certainty of the runners of those programs that those programs would continue. As the honourable senator would know, in 1981 the previous Government changed the funding of refuges to block grant funding under the community health program.

ANSWER.PARA: There always has been a problem in this area, particularly in States run by conservative governments and particularly in Queensland. Even from 1975 to 1981, when the other States were willing to make up the 25 per cent which was not taken up by the Federal Government with recurrent funding, the Queensland Government would pay only 12 1/2 per cent. It insisted on those who were running the refuges making a contribution by raising capital and recurrent funds, and it still persists with that policy today. The Tasmanian Government, the other conservative State Government, since 1981 has allowed funding for women's refuges to go down, so the services are suffering in those areas. The services are also suffering because there has been a lack of increase in the Commonwealth 's contribution through the community health scheme and because women's refuges more and more have to deal with women with psychiatric problems and problems outside the area that they were involved in before.

It is for this reason that we believe it is important that the program be a national one and that we get involved in it. We believe that the attitude of the Queensland Government and the Tasmanian Government that women who are bashed or otherwise maltreated at home should stay with their husbands because they signed some marriage vows is a disgusting one. We believe that for that reason there needs to be national involvement. To add an even greater perception to Disraeli' s description of conservative governments as 'organised hypocrisy', in Queensland and Tasmania most of the women who go to women's refuges are taken to them by State instrumentalities such as the police and local community welfare associations. On the one hand, people such as Mr Hinze in Queensland and Mr Cleary in Tasmania deplore the existence of women's refuges, saying that women should stay at home and be bashed, and at the same time the very people--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a gross misrepresentation.
—The honourable senator does not represent organised hypocrisy; she represents disorganised hypocrisy.
—Order! The honourable senator should withdraw that remark.

—Mr President, I withdraw. On the one hand a State government is saying that it is opposed to refuges and on the other it is using its own authorities to take people to them so that they can be properly cared for. For all these reasons we intend to introduce an emergency program so that, in co- operation with the States, we can ensure that the people who run these refuges, who are and at the moment, underpaid and working under great difficulties, will have something to look forward to, rather than the uncertainty they have faced in the last five years.
