DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS WAGE DEMANDS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to jobs posed by the ACTU's aggressive and unrealistic wage demands.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought forward a matter of public importance in the terms that you have just read, Mr Deputy President, because of our concern at the reported unanimous resolution of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive meeting yesterday. I understand the ACTU resolved to push a virtually non-negotiable claim for full indexation from the March quarter this year and threatened a wages free-for-all if it failed to get that from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I understand that the ACTU also wants this year a start on what it claims to be a 9.1 per cent catch-up in wages since the last round of wage rises. The ACTU claims that its failure to get these claims which it is now putting forward and which Mr Dolan, the President of the ACTU, has described as not being ambit claims would seriously disturb the prices and incomes accord which it signed with the Australian Labor Party prior to the formation of the present Hawke Government. The news yesterday of that resolution led national employer organisations to reject the claim, and even yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was strenuously suggesting that there needed to be wage restraint for the next 18 months or so. If we contrast the statements of the national employer organisations-and presumably of the Government, to judge from what the Prime Minister said as late as yesterday-strenuously urging maximum wage restraint with the unanimous resolution of the ACTU Executive we find very grave conflict. As was expressed in some leading articles today, the unions have put an end to consensus. In that context the Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance. I think it necessary to state the context in which the theme of consensus has been developed and by which the expectations of the Australian community were raised by being told that there was to be a sharing of the burden and a recognition of the need for a continuation of wage restraint. As was said by a number of employers at the recent National Economic Summit Conference, any increases in wages would result in further unemployment. I quote but one of the participants at the Summit, Mr Coates of the AMP Society. Amongst other things, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, I believe it is appropriate to say that in our present economic circumstances any shift of benefits to the employed will almost certainly be at the cost of the unemployed.

For those reasons perhaps we ought to go back to what has been said by members of the Government and others in the context of the Summit and in relation to the accord with the ACTU prior to the last election. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his speech to the Summit, spoke of the desire of the Government to provide 500, 000 jobs over the next three years. He said that this would require annual gross domestic product growth of over 4 per cent, a performance that has not been sustained in Australia during the past decade. Mr Keating talked of the need to endeavour to create employment and recognised the difficulties in the relationship of wages and profit to employability through the Australian community. I refer to one part of Mr Keating's speech in which he used the subtitle 'prices and incomes policy'. He stated that the other component of the government's economic strategy was the prices and incomes policy, and said:

Its rationale, and what it can and cannot reasonably be expected to achieve, are outlined in this statement of accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That accord made the following points:

Without a prices and incomes policy, economic recovery will soon lead to increased inflation, thus forcing the Government to adopt contractionary anti- inflation policies which will truncate the recovery;
A prices and incomes policy permits higher rates of economic growth, without incurring the circumscribing penalty of higher inflation;

Other points were made by Mr Keating on a number of occasions since the Summit and during the reporting of the Summit. I think it is fair to say that the Government stressed the need for maximum wage restraint in order to pursue the creation of the 500,000 jobs over the next three years which it claimed was possible if we had a higher rate of economic growth and were able to return to the profitable investment that needs to be employed to provide employment for Australians. The Prime Minister, in his address to the House of Representatives on 3 May in which he reported on the Economic Summit Conference, made a number of points and put before the Parliament the communique of that Conference. He noted the words of the communique which said:

The Australian economy is in deep recession. Economic activity and employment are continuing to fall and unemployment is still rising. Profits are depressed, and wage earners have had to accept deferral of improvements and maintenance of living standards. Inflation and interest rates remain high. There are signs of improvement in the world economy and of an end to the drought in the eastern States.

He made further comments along those lines, then turned to the more specific achievements of the Conference. He stressed that about three achievements of the Conference were all of equal importance. The first was the degree of common understanding reached on the nature and source of Australia's economic problems. The second was the degree of consensus reached, as expressed in the communique, on the basic framework and approach required to begin to arrest the decline in our economy, to arrest the expansion in unemployment levels and, in an ongoing sense, to put our economy on a path of sustained non-inflationary growth. Thirdly, he stressed that the first step had been taken and commitments had been given and that there was a recognition on all sides that the consensus reached was only that first step. He said that what needed to be done was to translate into effective action that consensus and that understanding which it was claimed were achieved at the Summit. I think we are at the point at which effective action needs to be taken to put into effect those claims of consensus made at the Summit, the need for economic recovery and our concern about the high numbers of unemployed and about those who will find difficulty in retaining and gaining employment in the future.

The key elements of the communique, as stressed by the Prime Minister, were that there be restraint in expectations and claims from all sections of the community except the impoverished and that an effective incomes and prices policy is essential if an expansionary fiscal policy is to be pursued without adverse consequences for inflation. He then talked about paragraph 18 of the communique-the recognition by the trade union movement that the maintenance of real wages will be an objective over time during a period of economic crisis. He said that a fourth element was that the suppression of sectional claims was essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances. That was the basis on which we have entered a month or two of public comment by the President of the ACTU and by others with regard to their understanding of their role in the seeking of a hearing of their wage claims.

It will be remembered that, at the Summit, it was decided and, I think, agreed- certainly there was consensus-that there would be a return to centralised wage fixing through the Arbitration Commission. Indeed, the Summit made no detailed effort to address itself to the future of wage levels or wage fixing because it was said that, as a result of the information that was revealed at the Summit and the fact that there had been a return to a central wage fixing approach, this would be dealt with in the hearings at the Arbitration Commission. I think that is why it is of some concern that the statement made yesterday by the President of the ACTU and the subsequent interviews that he gave on these subjects revealed that he believed that the ACTU Executive's approach to what is virtually full indexation and a return to some catch-up will need to be upheld in the Arbitration Commission or there will be a free for all approach. In an interview on the AM program today Mr Dolan was asked:
Does this mean . . . an end to the wages pause?
He answered, without any equivocation:
Well, certainly. Yes.

Therefore, the approach of the Government, of employers and, I think, of a wide cross section of the Summit, that believed that there ought to be restraint throughout 1983 at least and, in many cases, the opinion that it ought to extend further than that, has certainly not sustained any consensus with the President of the ACTU, as revealed in the statement he made yesterday. I repeat, that when asked:
Does this mean . . . an end to the wages pause?
Mr Dolan answered:
Well, certainly. Yes.
He was further asked a question in regard to the Commission knocking back a claim. This was a reference to the claim that Mr Dolan describes as:
Not in any way an ambit claim. 2.2 per cent is quite clear. It was the movement in the CPI in the March quarter. In the March quarter. Now that is all we are claiming.
When asked:
If the Commission then knocks back such a claim, will you accept it?
Mr Dolan answered:
Well, they will put themselves out of business as far as I see it. There will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that increase.
When asked:
Is this the industrial free for all you are talking about.
Mr Dolan said:
That is right.

I do not think that we have any doubt as to the approach of the Leader of the ACTU with regard to the claims that he will pursue in the Arbitration Commission . But I think what will be of concern to all of us will be the response of the Government to that approach and to the submission that will be made in the public interest by the Government to those wage hearings and to some of the other meetings that are being held with regard to this matter. What interested me in the past few days was that I was not surprised to see the unanimous resolution of the ACTU Executive because of the things that Mr Dolan had been saying throughout April and May. A report on 21 April states:

The ACTU President, Mr Dolan, yesterday warned that union promises of restraint under the ACTU prices and incomes accord with the Federal Government would break down if the Arbitration Commission awarded less than full indexation under a new centralised wage system.

There was no approach in that report to anything less than full indexation, even though at the Summit the information that was given from many different quarters showed that full indexation would not improve employment prospects; indeed, it would add to unemployment. I think that what was said by Mr Dolan a little earlier on 17 May showed that the claim for consultation and consensus between the trade unions and the Government was not very healthy at that stage, because on 17 May it was reported:

The ACTU is today to look specifically at the wage rise they will seek at the resumed central wage fixing hearing. Mr Dolan said on the ABC PM program last night that Mr Hawke had never talked about a 3 to 4 per cent rise, that that figure must be the work of a journalist.

He then went on to make a comment about journalists and their imagination. I think that what was shown in that particular report in regard to Mr Dolan was that the consultation that we had been led to expect would occur between the trade union movement and the Government was obviously not clearly being undertaken between the two parties concerned because, if Mr Dolan was claiming at that time that the Prime Minister had not mentioned to him a 3 to 4 per cent increase this year, that is quite contrary to the statements that were being made by the Prime Minister. I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 3 May, page 81, where the Prime Minister said:

. . . I believe that an increase of the order of 3 per cent to 4 per cent and no more by the end of this year will be consistent with a situation in which the Australian economy will be able to move into 1984 . . .

With some prospects of 'growth' and 'recovery'. To hear the Leader of the ACTU say, as late as this report on 17 May, that he had not heard that the Prime Minister was using that figure makes me wonder exactly what is to be upheld with regard to the prices and incomes accord. One of the conditions of that prices and incomes accord that were agreed upon by the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement prior to the election was:

To protect the purchasing power of wages and salaries the adoption of a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported in tripartite consultations and before industrial tribunals.

If that is the accord which Mr Dolan seems to believe should be upheld, I think it is fair enough for us to ask what the submission of the Government will be to the Arbitration Commission. On behalf of the ACTU, Mr Dolan is asking for full indexation and commencement of catch-up of a 9.1 per cent increase that he says has not been given to the trade union movement since the last wage hearing. In the accord is the objective to protect full indexation and the full cost of living increases and the pledge that the Labor Party, if in government, would support these in tripartite consultations and before industrial tribunals. It is also stated in the accord:
Where over award payments exist the Government will support the maintenance of those levels in real terms to ensure consistency between paid rates and amounts paid under minimum rates awards.

Some other aspects of that agreement are the proposals with regard to income tax and other consultations that are to be held between the two parties concerned. Because of this accord and the fact that Mr Dolan has said from time to time that his union movement is more interested in the prices and incomes accord than in some of the matters that may have been dealt with at the Summit, I pose the question whether it is the prices and incomes accord that is the policy that will bind the present Government with the trade union movement in accord or in consensus to endeavour to have full cost of living adjustments upheld before the hearings that are shortly to take place. If that is the case-if the accord is the document that binds the two parties-there must be some concern with regard to the prospects of improving employment opportunities. None of the scenarios, A , B or C, that were presented at the Summit gave the impression that it would be easy to produce the 500,000 additional jobs that the Australian Labor Party has claimed it could or would want to provide within the next three years. If we look at the three scenarios that were put before the Summit, we would have to wonder whether the very serious claim of the ACTU before the Commission-that is, not the ambit claim-is more likely to look like scenario B than either of the other two scenarios. If that is the case, and if we are looking at a scenario which is the maintenance of real wages and full indexation and which talks of a catch up-the words, 'over time' can mean anything in anyone's interpretation-of wage increases that have been foregone and full indexation in the future, that looks like scenario B. In that case, in the next year or two an unemployment level of something over 12 per cent is the frightening prospect that looks likely to occur.

It was for these reasons that we felt it was timely to hear from the Government . I assume that the Government will say: 'We will discuss these matters before the Commission'. I am not expecting the Government to come forward and say that it will reveal in this set-up today what, in the public interest, its submissions will be to the Commission. I fully accept that that is something that needs to be done in its own way, and in the way in which it usually is done , as a submission directly to the Conciliation and Abritration Commission.

What concerns me is the matter which has now been raised by the ACTU and which seems to be calling up the IOU on the prices and incomes accord with the Government and the IOU which talks about full indexation. The Government seems to be abandoning what might have been the realisation of the state of the Australian economy, from the information that was given by those who were represented at that Summit Conference. To talk now about our concern of the prospects of employment improvement is something that is worthy of our attention in this place today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic of the matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to jobs posed by the ACTU's aggressive and unrealistic wage demands.

I suppose if any expression in Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's well balanced speech was used more than once, more than 10 times or more than 20 times, it was the expression 'I wonder'. We have all heard of Alice in Wonderland. The speech which we have just heard is 'Margaret in Wonderland'. That is what the speech has been about. She said: 'I wonder what will happen if. I wonder what will happen then. I wonder what will happen after that'. The process of wondering is a legitimate one, but it is not, in a sense, a constructive contribution to the issue which was raised under the matter of public importance, which is:
The threat to jobs posed by the ACTU's aggressive and unrealistic wage demands.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has been reciting the collected works or comments of Cliff Dolan, as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which have brought about in her a state of wonderment. She asked: 'Does this mean an end to the wages pause?'. Not in the Government's view.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does, in Mr Dolan's view.
—It does, in the ACTU's view.

—Yes, I know. What I am really saying is that honourable senators opposite are really playing the same old record. Let me put it in some perspective right at the beginning. It was very interesting that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle made no attempt to address herself to the question of what the Opposition feels about the issue of declining standards of living, particularly among lower income workers. Has not the whole issue got to be looked at in this context? I put it to honourable senators opposite in this way: Unless this Government adopts a coherent wages policy, delivers its promises and develops a working relationship between government, employer and employees in industrial relations, there is little hope that inflation will be contained and the conditions set for growth in our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to honourable senators opposite also that there are major pressures on Australia's economy. It will be a crucial year if we have no national wages policy and ineffectual communications between government and the trade union movement. They are not my words; they are the words of the former Prime Minister in January 1982. He said: 'Unless we have a good relationship with the unions, unless we have a wages policy, then these things will follow: There will be no growth. There will be increasing unemployment'. That is what was said in January 1982 and that is what the former Government did last year. I will come to the details of some of that in a minute.

Today Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle talked about the National Economic Summit Conference and the views which were expressed at that Summit. She talked about the prices and wages accord and analysed the details of that document with some precision. Then, as I have said, she expressed wonderment about whether all these things would happen. Of course it is true that Mr Dolan has made a number of remarks on behalf of the ACTU about the ACTU's views in respect of a wages policy. Mr Dolan is like Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle; he has a constituency to represent. He has this much in common with Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle: Both constituencies are getting smaller-Mr Dolan's because of unemployment and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's because of the sorts of arguments which have been put in the Senate today and which were put by coalition spokesmen and spokeswomen when they were in government for the last couple of years. That is why the constituencies are getting smaller. That is why the Opposition is now so concerned about the question of consensus-something which it was never able to attain in government and something which it bitterly resents this Government having attained.

When we talk about the question of consensus this matter of public importance is brought forward in relation to the Government's wages policy. I do not think we had when we were in opposition many headlines such as 'Opposition Split on Wages Policy'. That headline appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 5 May. The article stated that the Opposition had not yet reached agreement, as at 5 May, and it foreshadowed a long discussion about whether the Opposition adhered to or agreed with the Summit view that there should be a centralised wage fixation system. If there had not been a move towards a centralised wage fixation system, which is the subject of discussion now in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we would have had the sort of chaos that characterised the Fraser years in terms of industrial relations and wages policy.

I want to make one or two comments about that. First of all, let me deal with the nub of the issue. Wage levels in 1983-84, as foreshadowed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her comments, will be determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and will be determined by the Commission in the light of a view which the Goverment will be putting to it about the desirability of restraint throughout the community. Senator Hamer should not smile at that comment. That has been said a hundred times and I am saying it again.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are committed, by your accord, to support quarterly wage indexation.

—I am just saying that the view that will be put to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will be put in the light of the Government's view about the need for restraint throughout the community. We do not hear very much about that issue from the Opposition. All we hear is what we have always heard-that the sector upon which restraints should be imposed, irrespective of anything else which happens in the economy, is the wages sector. That is why the former Government invented the wages freeze as it was called. That is why it was unable to reach a conclusion, as a government, last year and early this year, as to when the wages pause or freeze would end. That was the level of commitment that the former Government gave to the trade union movement. I put that in the light of the former Prime Minister's comments about the necessity for commitment to, and consultation with, the trade union movement. The former Government never gave the trade union movement or the work force of this country any indication as to when the wages pause would end. So I think Mr Dolan is entitled to make comments about when he thinks it should end.
—When do you say it should end?
—The Government has said on a number of occasions that we wish to maintain wage restraint throughout this calendar year. We have also said--
—That is what we were saying.

—That is very clever. The honourable senator has got it right for once. He was saying the same thing as us. Congratulations! In the knowledge that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will have a claim before it this year we have said that we will be putting a submission to the inquiry before the Commission. It may well mean that there is an increase in wages which, provided it is within the sorts of restraints which we seek, we as a government believe can be accommodated consistent with economic recovery. We do not believe that the sole determinant of economic recovery and the sole determinant of competitiveness in Australian industry is wages as do Opposition members, who keep repeating it to the exclusion of everything else.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of this matter of public importance which is raised today is a new-found concern with a threat to jobs. That is really something when we look at the Opposition's record on that matter. The greatest threat to jobs in this country in the last eight years has been a Liberal-National Country Party government. I am reminded of a comment Mr Whitlam made some years ago about Mr Snedden's new bodyguard in 1974 when I hear Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle speak on this issue, as I was when Senator Chaney spoke a week ago. He said it was not so much to stop someone shooting him as to stop him shooting himself. That is the argument which has in fact been put here today. Senator Chaney and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle could both do with new bodyguards.

In the seven years of the previous Government the number of Australians unemployed increased by 400,200 or 118 per cent. The increase in unemployment under the Fraser Government from February 1976 to February 1983 was 118 per cent . Unemployment reached levels unparalleled since the Great Depression. By the time the previous Government was beaten one in 10 Australians were out of work and one in four teenage Australians were unable to find work. In the previous Government's last year of office unemployment increased by more than a quarter of a million or 54.3 per cent. As a new Government we suffer from the disastrous effects of the policies of the previous Government. The whole of industry suffers from the disastrous effects of the absence of any wages policy under the previous Government. From the middle of 1981 until the end of 1982, when the so- called wages pause was plucked out of the head of the then member for Macarthur- -

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—Yes, it was his idea. The then Government had to be seen to be doing something, so the wages pause was invented and that was the end of--
—I thought you said we did not do anything. Now you are saying we introduced the wages pause.

—Yes, I am saying the previous Government invented the wages pause late last year. The point I make is that the problems which this Government inherits and the problems which Australian industry inherits are problems which were created as a result of a total absence of a wages policy in 1981 and the first half of 1982. When the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd announces a steel price rise it says: 'That is due to wage increases in part'. One asks: 'How can it be due to wage increases? We have had a wage pause?' It says: 'It is due to the wage increases which flowed through the system from 1981 -82 when there was a record increase in wages because of the total absence of a wages policy'. That is one of the reasons for the dramatic increases in unemployment in the calendar year 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Government is concerned about general restraint in the community , including restraint of wages. We will approach the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in order to seek an atmosphere of general restraint. The whole prices and incomes accord is based on the view that if we are to have an economic recovery in Australia it has to be on the basis that the burdens and the benefits of that recovery are being shared between various sectors of the community. That is why we are putting into place a prices surveillance mechanism and why we have talked about a very minimal level of wage increases in the expectation of a possible recovery later in the year. So the real problem which this Government has-we feel saddened by an attempt to divert us from our course on these matters-is to overcome the vast difficulties which have been caused by the absence of a wages policy, a matter which Senator Lewis knows about. I am smiling only because I was beginning to sound like Senator Walsh talking about wages policy. But I am confining my remarks to wages policy and Senator Walsh devotes his comments to a much wider range of economic vicissitudes which have been visited on this country by our predecessors. In the area of wages policy alone the effects on industry and so on have been enormous.

We are chided here because Mr Dolan said something. The best way to make clear one's views about Mr Dolan if he does not listen to the Senate-he may listen; I would not think so-is to put out a Press release on behalf of the Liberal- National Party Opposition saying that his recent comments pose an aggressive and unrealistic threat to jobs. I think members of the Opposition should put out such a Press release if that is their view and carry on the debate in that arena , if they want to do that. But I think Mr Dolan will then say: 'Look, who are you to talk? You have got us into all our present problems. Who are you to talk about this sort of issue?' In a sense that is all I am saying about the remarks made by Mr Dolan.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is going to say the same to your Government too, isn't he? ' Who are you to talk?'
—He will go to the Arbitration Commission, the unions will make their submissions and the Commission will deal with them.
—With your support.

—I have declined to say what approach the Government will make, but I have said, in a manner which I think even Senator Messner can understand, that the Government will approach the Arbitration Commission in an atmosphere of urging general restraint within the community. I think the honourable senator could even twig to what that means. If he reads the transcript of the AM program this morning he will see that Mr Willis made that quite clear in the course of an interview. The Opposition is really wondering whether the Government will be stood over by Mr Dolan or anybody else on a wages policy. Mr Dolan is not the sort of person who stands over anybody and he would not, I believe, seek to stand over the Government. But the Government's policies on wage restraint, the desirability of reducing unemployment and the extraordinary mess we have inherited from past years, are quite clear. In the fullness of time they will be unravelled-partly tomorrow and partly when the Arbitration Commission meets to consider these matters. They are being partly dealt with now in the context of discussions in the Commission about a centralised wage fixation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, those processes will take a little time. But there is no intention, on the basis of statements made by anybody in the Opposition, in the ACTU or anywhere else, to depart from the general policy approach the Government enunciated at the Summit, has enunciated since and will continue to enunciate. No doubt we will make a few errors here and there. I do not retreat from that. I suppose that remark will be the subject of Question Time next week. I do not retreat from that. No doubt we will make a few errors here and there. But the broad policy thrust is quite clear. It is sad that there should be attempts to undermine by an Opposition which has lost the capacity-perhaps it never had it- for obtaining consensus in Australian society about the real issues which concern the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a matter of public importance which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to jobs posed by the ACTU's aggressive and unrealistic wage demands.

This must be seen against the background of the present Australian economic situation. This was very well discussed at the recent National Economic Summit Conference and I give credit to the Government for the amount of economic information it made available to the community during that Summit. It was quite clear-I think there was general agreement-that the facts of our present situation are that our inflation rate is double that of our trading partners, our growth is negative, our interest rates are non-affordable to certain sections of the community and profitability is at historically low levels. I would like to emphasise that out of profits comes investment and out of investment come jobs. If profits are starved jobs cannot be created.

There is no doubt at all-I think even Senator Button and I might agree on this- that for an intrinsically rich country, which we are, we are in a sorry economic state. One of the worst manifestations of this is the unemployment rate of over 700,000 people. I think there was also general agreement at that Summit that we must fight unemployment and inflation simultaneously. This I believe was an important agreement and one which does credit to all concerned. At the Summit the Government put forward three scenarios about the impact of wages primarily on inflation and unemployment. These scenarios have been mentioned by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle because they are central to this whole argument about wages. I would like to run through them again. Three scenario projections were proposed which, by their very nature, cannot be certain. They do give guidance as to how the economy might perform and what the consequences of different wage movements would be.

Projection C was the low wage, low inflation outcome. This was based on half yearly indexation of wages so that no additional wages would be paid until April 1984 and after that there would be 80 per cent indexation. Projection B was the other extreme-the high wage, high inflation outcome with full payment of the catch-up this July for the effect of the wage pause and full automatic consumer price index increases quarterly after that. Projection A was the intermediate case with no catch-up, some wage increase later this year to be followed by full quarterly indexation starting next year. These are projections and they have dramatically different results.

The two preferable projections-that is, the low inflation, low wage increase projection and the intermediate projection-both would result in an increase in the number of jobs available and in growth. But the high wage projection has negative effects on jobs. We would not be creating new jobs. We would be creating more unemployment and, worse still, our inflation rate would be higher. If we took this option of the high wage rate we would be doing immense damage to the unemployed and to our trading pattern with other countries. Yet this is the course, with minor modifications, which the Australian Council of Trade Unions is now proposing to follow. On the Government's own figures this will do great harm to the unemployed. It will increase the number of unemployed. It will not even approach solving the unemployment problem and will push up our inflation rate to a level far beyond those of our trading partners. Yet this is the pattern proposed by the ACTU. I thought it was agreed at the Summit that some sacrifices by the 90 per cent of people in work were necessary so that there would be a fair deal for the 10 per cent unemployed. Now the ACTU, with Government support-a matter I will come to in a moment-is proposing to jettison and sacrifice the unemployed. Jobs for the boys is their motto but they mean jobs for the boys in work and be damned to those who are unemployed.

The memory of the Summit is fading now. I suppose some people still remember it . It was a public relations success at the time and people did leave with a feeling of euphoria that Australians had come together, looked at their problems and realised that they had to make a common effort to solve them. I think nearly all the give was on one side. Employers gave an agreement on centralised wage fixing which, after all, got us into our present problems. Employers accepted-I think this was a quite proper acceptance-that restraint is not only a matter for the wage earners but also that it must extend right across the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you oppose centralised wage fixation? Are you one of those people who oppose Ian Macphee?

—I will come in a moment to the dangers of centralised wage fixing and how to guard against its dangers. The employers agreed on centralised wage fixing and I think that in practical terms they had no option. We have a long history of centralised wage fixing. Our industrial system works on that basis and I think it would not be realistic to try to continue without centralised wage fixing. But what was not agreed at the Summit was for how long the wage pause would last. All the Government's projections showed that it was most important for the unemployed and the inflation rate that the wage pause should last as long as possible, preferably into next year. Now the President of the ACTU says that the wage pause is over and the Government will have to go along with him. That is a point I will come to in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Summit there was no agreement on how long the wage pause should last. There was no agreement on how future wage adjustments should be made. There were many criticisms of the CPI as an appropriate measure. There was no agreement on what is a more appropriate measure. Most important of all perhaps is the fact that there was no tackling of this problem of comparative wage justice-the flow- on whereby powerful unions can pick off particular industries that are profitable. Then that whole wage structure which they have negotiated for people who can afford it, flows right across the board to industries that cannot afford it. This would have done so much harm to our industries in Australia. There was no agreement on these points. All these were thrown back to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and everyone hoped for the best.

But at least people went away from the Summit thinking that scenario A-that is, the intermediate one with some wage restraint, a small increase towards the end of this year and indexation next year-had at least been agreed to. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is on record as saying that he thinks a wage increase of 3 to 4 per cent might be appropriate towards the end of this year. That is not what the unions are asking for. I will come to that in a moment. The unions are asking for much more than that, but Mr Hawke thought that that sort of increase would be appropriate. Apparently, according to Mr Dolan, Mr Hawke never got around to telling Mr Dolan of that. Now the ACTU is applying for immediate indexation from the March quarter and, as is quite apparent from Mr Dolan's conversation, it will go on demanding quarterly wage increases immediately knowing what the consequences will be for our inflation rate and for the unemployed. What will the Government's attitude be when these matters come before the Arbitration Commission? Senator Button was saying that the Government would be urging wage restraint. Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, has said that the Government's submissions will be based on the results of the Summit and on the prices and incomes accord with the ACTU. I would like to read one section of the accord:
Accordingly it is agreed that to protect the purchasing powers of wages and salaries, the adoption of a system of full cost-of-living adjustments will be strongly supported--
Strongly supported by the Government, I suppose--
. . . in tripartite consultations and before industrial tribunals.

The ACTU is not calling in its debts and the Government is committed by the accord, which it has signed and on which it fought the last election, to supporting the demand of the ACTU for full wage indexation. The consequences of this on unemployment and inflation-on the Government's own figures-will be catastrophic, but that is what the Government is now doing. The ACTU is calling in its debts and the Government is committed to supporting the ACTU in what is, by its own economic projections, an outrageously damaging thing to the whole community. So much for the pious remarks which were made at the Summit. I will read a few of them; I think they sound rather odd in the light of what the ACTU has done since. These are the remarks-they were very well received at the time- of Mr Kelty of the ACTU. He said:
The task therefore is to develop a set of integrated policies the aim of which is to increase employment and reduce the inflation rate.

Yet the action the ACTU is now taking will do the exact opposite. This is what it said only a short time ago, in the euphoric atmosphere of the Summit, and now it is taking actions which will have exactly the opposite effect. Mr Kelty also said:
The ACTU believes that the priority must be employment growth.
Yet the Government is doing more for the people in work, and be damned to the unemployed. Mr Kelty continued:
We accept that seeking the achievement of lower rates of inflation and higher levels of employment will involve moderation in wage demands.

What is meant by the word 'moderation' is a matter for discussion. It is quite evident that what Mr Dolan considers moderation to be is full quarterly indexation, despite the fact that the Government's own projections show that we cannot afford it if we are to tackle the problems of unemployment and inflation. The ACTU calls that moderation. It is a bit like Genghis Khan who created a desert and called it peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call it?
—I call it a disastrously foolish policy, and it will have very grave consequences for people whom the ACTU claims to be in favour of-the unemployed and the community as a whole. Mr Kelty then said:

SPEECH.PARA: We all need to make some difficult decisions if employment is to be increased.

The ACTU has made some difficult decisions. The difficult decisions are that it will not do anything about unemployment; there will be more for the people in work. This is the final quote I will give from Mr Kelty:
We need to ensure the employed have a commitment to the unemployed and that we do not develop a privileged elite within the work force.

The latter is exactly what the ACTU is doing. I will quote again from some of the promises and undertakings made at the Summit. The President of the ACTU, Mr Dolan-the man who is now effectively breaking any hope of tackling, in the short term, this problem of unemployment-points out, and he is quite correct, that:
Sustained growth for several years of the order of five per cent a year is required if unemployment is to be attacked.

That is true. But the policies that the ACTU is now proposing-which the Government is committeed by its prices and incomes accord to support and argues strongly in support of them-will have a disastrous effect on our rate of growth. It will come down to probably under 2 per cent, if it increases at all. This is what the Government is committed to by its agreement. Finally, I will quote from the summary of the Summit, which was given by the Prime Minister. He said:

Specifically we set the following objectives for the conference and one of them was to devise machinery for achieving the necessary restraint, including methods of wage fixation influencing non-wage incomes and price surveillance.
The Government certainly did not succeed with regard to wage fixation. The Prime Minister also summed up one of the conclusions of the Summit. He stated:
There was recognition by the trade union movement for the maintenance of real wages, the objective over time during a period of economic crisis.

What the trade union movement wants is to have its cake now. It is quite clear from the Government's projections that in the last year or two we have been paying our work force more than the community can afford. It has had disastrous effects on our inflation rate. It has done great damage to profitability and the community as a whole is the sufferer. What we must aim for and what I hope the Government will disregard is its public commitment to the prices and incomes agreement with the ACTU-after all the Government has broken most of its other promises; I do not see why it should not break this one. It should break this one and fight strongly in the community interest, in the interests of the unemployed and in the interests of future growth to ensure that there is continuing wage restraint in this community. Only by that can we get out of our present economic difficulties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -The text of the matter of public importance refers to the threat to jobs posed by the ACTU. I thought we had had only one opinion poll on this matter recently. There was a sample of 8 million people. In that opinion poll it was quite clear that the Australian electorate said that the greatest threat which was posed to jobs was the Liberal-National Party Government. On 5 March the people made the decision to remove that Government out of office. What appears to have occurred with the traumatic shock of that among honourable senators opposite is some sort of political amnesia. Those opposite have forgotten that they are responsible for the majority of the unemployment that exists in this country at the moment. They were in power for over seven years and they had chances to implement policies to remedy areas such as wages policy or unemployment, but they failed to do so in any sort of consistent or constructive manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is, in terms of this Opposition, which brings forward these sorts of matters of public importance, that it has no wages policy whatsoever and has not had a wages policy in the last two years. Yet it is an issue that obsesses honourable senators opposite. Trade unions and wages are matters that obsess members of the Liberal-National Party. They can think of very little else; they can speak of very little else, yet they have no firm view on what constitutes a proper wages policy for Australia. Never do we hear a statement from them that constructively sets out what they regard as a proper wages policy for Australia. In the middle of 1981 the Liberal-National Party abandoned centralised wage fixing by going to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and arguing against indexation. It gave no thought to what would follow. It had no idea how wage movements would occur in the future once it got rid of indexation. Like all Liberal governments, but especially the one of the last three years, it thought two or three months in advance. It thought that one of the biggest problems in Australia was indexation, so it got rid of it. However, no thought was given to what would follow.

In the natural course of events what did follow was that the unions reached a situation of collective bargaining, and we saw a wages explosion in the latter half of 1981. When a wages explosion occurred in 1973-74 honourable senators opposite blamed the Government. However, when a wages explosion occurred while they were in government they blamed the Australian Council of Trade Unions or any other scapegoat they could find. The wages explosion in 1981-82 had the effect of maintaining Australia's rate of inflation at a far higher rate than that of any of the comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We now have an inflation rate of over 10 per cent and our major trading partners have an inflation rate of 5 per cent.

The previous Government-the Liberal government-laid down the pre-conditions for that explosion and as my leader, Senator Button, indicated, its solution to it, thought-up on the run, thought up as an act of desperation, was a wage freeze. It later became a wage pause, which apparently is a more acceptable term, but it wanted a wage freeze. Of course that was allied with the fact that honourable senators opposite wanted an early Federal election. Most of those plans went down the drain when the then Prime Minister's back cracked. Honourable senators opposite decided on a wages pause. We debated the wages pause here last year time and again. Many questions were directed to the relevant Ministers, including one by me, asking Senator Chaney and Senator Sir John Carrick what will happen after the wages pause. Senator Button, Senator Walsh and others continually said: 'You have a wages freeze on, what happens following that? What will be your wages policy?' All we got were evasive answers, non-answers. Honourable senators opposite had no idea. That was the response from a government that thought two or three months into the future, and no further. Economic policy was developed in such a way as to meet an immediate crisis without thinking of long term goals. We never received an answer as to what was the Liberal-National Party attitude to wages policy.

We have had two Opposition speakers in this debate today, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Hamer. What did they say should be the future of Australia 's wages policy? They have no idea. They have not worked it out. They were in Government for seven years and did not work it out. Now they are in Opposition, they presumably have a little more time to cogitate on these sorts of matters. Again, they can come forward with no suggestion whatsoever as to what the future policy should be. Another Opposition speaker, Senator Lewis, is to follow later. He might like to answer these questions: How long do Liberal Party senators want the wages freeze to go on? Do they in fact support a return to centralised wage fixation? Should wage fixation be based on indexation? Should wage fixation be based on productivity? Should it be based on a combination of those sorts of factors? How do we bring about some sort of equality into the wages policy in Australia? The Liberal Party has no answer. Instead it puts up pious resolutions attacking the ACTU, as it has done for years with its union bashing tactics. It should come up with a constructive alternative.

This Government will be making its position clear before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It made it clear at the National Economic Summit Conference. Senator Button again made it clear that we are in favour of wage restraint for this year. What the Liberals really are on about is to get rid of centralised wage fixing and to leave it to the market forces. What they do not seem to understand is that the market forces have not solved the economic problems in this country. I understand, of course, that, with the absence of so many dries on the other side now-nearly all of them fell at the last poll-that is not even a popular view over there, but the remnants of their beliefs are still there. Their view is that somehow the market mechanism will re -establish market growth. They say that all we really need to do is to hold down wages for another six months or nine months.

That brings me to the subject as to how long the Opposition would like the wages pause to go. Does it really want it to go for nine months or for nine years? To what extent does the Liberal-National Party want to reduce the Australian standard of living? At what point will they be satisfied? Can Opposition senators produce a graph? Can they produce evidence that, when the standard of living of the average Australian reaches a certain point, economic growth will start to come into effect? They cannot do it because they have no idea how to do it.

I must say that it has become apparent during this debate that the Liberal Party fails to understand the Australian Labor Party's relationship with the trade union movement and Government decision making. We are not responsible for the decisions of the ACTU. That does not mean that we are not free either to support it or to oppose it, but we are not automatically locked into every decision of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We make our decisions as to the future of the wages policy on the basis of the benefit to the whole of Australia. We do not just comply because the ACTU believes that this or that should occur.

I was quite surprised when Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in her opening remarks, was talking about the reported resolutions from the ACTU. I take it that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has not read the resolutions, has not sought to get a copy of the resolutions and is relying on Press reports of what the ACTU is supposed to be doing or is not supposed to be doing. For instance, in the actual statement, the ACTU, when referring to the catch-up of 9.1 per cent, uses the following qualification: 'Consistent with the progress of economic recovery'. That is, it will not pursue the 9.1 per cent figure until the time is ripe or until the economic circumstances exist in which they can pursue that claim.

In conclusion, this has probably been the first time when the Opposition has brought up a debate concerning a matter with some major relevance to economics. It has been very noticeable here at Question Time and during the discussion of matters of public importance that the Opposition has avoided discussion of all economic topics. Are Opposition senators not interested in the future of interest rates in this country? Are they not interested in the growth of the housing industry? Are they not interested in what is happening to the rate of inflation? The reason why they fail to introduce these topics here is that those opposite must bear the guilt for the destruction of the Australian economy in the last seven years. I can recall quite clearly that the Whitlam Government was blamed even five or six years after its existence for some of the economic ills of this country. Yet a comparison between the dimensions of the economic problems that occurred in Australia towards the end of 1975 with those that occurred at the start of 1983 make the Whitlam days look like heaven.

We have unemployment running at a rate of 10 per cent. Those opposite seem to have forgotten that point. Have they forgotten that interest rates are at a record high and which Government was responsible in the last seven years for bringing about that situation? Have they forgotten that economic growth this year may well go into the negative for the first time since the Great Depression ? Have Opposition senators forgotten all those matters? No. All the Opposition can do is produce a carping matter of public importance attacking the ACTU for its wages policy. All I can say about the ACTU is that it has a wages policy. The Liberal-National Party Opposition does not have a wages policy and does not look like having a wages policy. It is doubtful whether, before the next election, it will have a wages policy. It is up to the Opposition, if it is to bring up matters like this for discussion, to put up some alternative. Where do Opposition senators want wage fixation in this country to go in the future?

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot make up their minds.

—As Senator Cook said, they cannot make up their minds. They have no idea of addressing the problem. They have no idea of addressing any economic problem because they are in tatters. They have had their chance. They have had 7 1/2 years to try to redress the economic problems of this country and they have failed totally. Now they are seeking to be absolved from the blame and to find a scapegoat. They say: 'Let us blame the ACTU. Let us blame someone else '. As far as I and, I am sure, everyone on this side of the Senate are concerned , that argument does not wash. The discussion of this matter of public importance serves only to highlight the bankruptcy that exists on the Opposition benches and which will continue to do so until Opposition senators start to tackle the real problems and come forward with some solutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats enter this debate because we want to express our concern at the cracks that seem to be appearing in the amity and apparent accord that followed the election and which were especially evident at the National Economic Summit Conference. We always regarded that accord as very fragile and valuable. It is fragile because of increasing tensions in the community due to the state of the economy and especially because of the undoubted fact that, while a wage pause is current, the prices of many goods and services are rising and inflation has indeed not been contained. If the trend of the first quarter of this year continues, inflation will be 8.8 per cent this year. The subject of this matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition for discussion is:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to jobs posed by the ACTU's aggressive and unrealistic wage demands.

I cannot quite see at this stage that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has yet made aggressive and unrealistic wage demands. I would agree that, if it did, that certainly would represent a threat to jobs. I think this is the crux of the matter.

We are reaching a point of danger, a point at which the consensus and the accord we talked about in recent weeks is at threat. Surely this is the attitude and the line which should be taken. It is not a time for confrontation; it is not a time for aggressiveness; it is a time for trying to make sure that that accord is continued and that we achieve something. Because of statements made already in the Senate about what the President of the ACTU, Mr Dolan, has said over the last 24 hours, I have obtained a transcript of his statements on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program, AM, this morning to assist my memory . It is a fact that in answer to this question:
. . . has the accord of the Summit effectively been destroyed?
Mr Dolan said:

Oh, the contrary, you know, don't tell me, how can you argue a 2.2 per cent wage increase application is not constraint. You know the consumer price index has moved by 11.5 per cent since the last wage increases took place.

To do Mr Dolan justice, some statements bandied around that he is proposing a free-for-all seem a little out of context. I think it is worth while looking at the transcript to get the matter back into context. Mr Dolan was asked:
. . . given the Federal Government's own call for restraint, do you think the ACTU executive decision cuts against that, cuts across the Government?
Mr Dolan replied:
No, I repeat again, I believe that is complete wage restraint. And you know, restraint doesn't mean that you don't get any wage increase at all.

On the other hand, if the consumer price index is going to continue to move in the same way, and perhaps as you've suggested, you know, 2.2 per cent increase in the next three quarters of this year, well then certainly that's 10 per cent virtually for the year, you know a wage and salary earner's expected to have their standard of living reduced by 10 per cent?
The interviewer then said:
Does this mean then an end to the wages pause?
Mr Dolan answered:
Well certainly, yes.
I suggest to honourable senators that here we have the point of stress and danger. A little later, the interviewer asked:
And if the Arbitration Commission knocks back such a claim you will accept it?
I stress that that is in reference to the 2.2 per cent only. Mr Dolan said:
Well, they will . . . put themselves out of business as far as I see it. You know there will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that increase.
The interviewer then asked:
This is industrial free for all you are talking about?
Mr Dolan answered:
That's right.

That is the sort of context in which we have to look at this matter. As I have said, it seems a pity that this matter should become one of confrontation politics at this time. Surely there are danger signals in what I have just quoted which everybody should recognise. Now, far more than at the time of the National Economic Summit Conference-which was during a honeymoon period-there is a real need for careful, reasoned debate. There is also a need to recognise that behind this issue remain the basic problems of the economy, that the Government has been elected to solve those problems and that those others of us here, the Liberal-National Party Opposition and the Australian Democrats, have a duty to share in the solution of those problems. That is what we are here for. One basic intractable problem is productivity, which is plainly an important factor in the economic equation. Article 8 of the Summit communique states:
It is a legitimate expectation that income of the employed shall be increased in real terms through time in line with productivity.

There is a problem here in that productivity in Australia is not increasing at anything more than a minuscule rate-0.2 of one per cent in 1981-82 for non-farm product per person employed. That is in spite of new technology and in spite of the fact that in other countries new methods, new technology and new ideas have increased productivity dramatically. This is an intractable problem in our society which ought not be intractable. It is one to which we should address ourselves. In fact, a closer association of incomes with productivity, if it could be achieved, in some cases would be of great value.

In comparison with the increase in productivity, real average weekly ordinary time earnings for adult males in full time employment rose by 3 per cent in 1980 -81 and 4.4 per cent in 1981-82. Those figures are taken from the working papers of the Summit. We recognise that not everybody has benefited from these increases and we are concerned about the effects of inflation and prices on low income earners. This is an area which should concern all honourable senators because there is a certain level below which people cannot be squeezed and still maintain any decent semblance of a reasonable life. If people have only a certain very low income and yet prices go up around them, they are almost forced to a point of desperation, to a stage where their children literally go without food, proper clothing and things of that kind. That, therefore, is a special area of need which we ought properly to recognise. We wish the Government would.

That does not really go along with what Mr Dolan has been saying. He has been talking about overall wage increases whereas, surely, the problem of the country should be solved by applying some discrimination and applying those of our slender resources we can spare to those who need help most. I would have thought that a trade unionist with the standing, background and history of Mr Dolan would recognise that and would recognise the trend of his organisation's policies.

The Democrats are also concerned with the effects of a general wage rise, some of which would flow to people who have already received substantial pay increases. What effect will this have on the already historically low profit levels of business? I do not think anyone can dispute that there is only one way in which employment can basically be increased in this country, and that is in the private sector. There is no future in putting more and more people on the public payroll to build new toilet blocks in Woop Woop, much as Woop Woop might like new toilet blocks. This is not the answer to increasing productivity and the basic wealth of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't knock Woop Woop. It is a very pleasant town.

—I am sorry for saying nasty things about Woop Woop. I apologise publicly to the people of Woop Woop. Senator Chipp's interjection reminds me that he has said in this place-I agree with him very much; we pushed this point during the election campaign-that if we created conditions for small business in Australia in which each business could employ just one more person then we would not have any unemployment. That does not seem to us to be an impossible objective. It seems the sort of objective that should be looked at rather than what has been said so far in this debate and what indeed seems so far to be the attitude of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that we worry about low income earners and that we are concerned that pay rises would flow on to people who already have had inceases, we are doing no more that supporting the Economic Summit communique. We do that because, although we did not participate in that august assembly, we believe it was of great value and it did achieve a unique measure of consensus in general terms, certainly in the short term. We now call on the participants to construe this consensus into reality. It is of no use Mr Hawke or the Government putting full page solemn advertisements in newspapers that 'The Summit continues' unless people can see some results. They do not want to be told just that the Summit continues; they want something to happen. I would rather see the money which was spent on those advertisements spend on new toilet blocks at Woop Woop. At least the people at Woop Woop would have got them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That is something that might be considered. Senator Lewis, I am not really interested in hearing 'hear, hear!' from the Opposition on this matter because it seems to me, looking back over the last few years, that the previous Government was not averse to spending money on advertisements itself. Let us put that in its proper context, too. The Summit communique further states :

SPEECH.PARA: Economic activity and employment are continuing to fall and unemployment is still rising. Profits are depressed; and wage earners have had to accept deferral of improvements and maintenance of living standards.

That is a basic synopsis of the situation. We support the Government in pursuing its intentions to solve this problem. I think Mr Hawke and senior members of the Government have made it fairly plain that they want wage restraint; that they want to overcome this terrible economic bind this country is in. I ask: How serious are the unions now in accepting their role in this respect? I stress yet again that it is a borderline situation; we are on the brink of something. This is why it is so important that this matter be sorted out as quickly as possible.

The Australian Democrats think that we might all be better off if the ACTU pressed claims on behalf of low income earners so that they could be compensated for the effects of inflation. If the Government could do that in its mini-Budget , perhaps using fiscal measures to achieve these aims, it would do a lot more for the community. I ask: Is the ACTU concerned about those of its members who have not achieved a pay rise and whose low incomes have caused them economic hardship? Is the ACTU concerned for those people who have experienced the hardship of unemployment, or is it concerned about maintaining the living standards of those employed people who can well afford to make some sacrifice for the sake of the community and who were committed to doing so by the ACTU at the Summit? That is the hard question that has to be asked of the ACTU and I would be delighted if at some stage Mr Dolan gave us an answer in specific terms . If not, if indeed it favours maintaining the living standards of those who can afford to make some sacrifice, then can we say that consensus is over? Have the unions decided to put self-interest before employment? The Summit agreed that employment should be placed before self-interest. Will the trade unions accept point 14 of the communique, which says that the timing or quantum-whatever that might mean-of wage increases is a matter for the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Today, Mr Dolan said:
. . . there will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that increase.

That statement is a threat not only to the intentions of the Summit but also to the structure that the Summit agreed would be in charge of wage fixing. We are not convinced by the fact that the 2.2 per cent claim is still less than the 3 per cent to 4 per cent figure the Government wants to achieve-Mr Hawke is on record as saying that-because unless inflation for the rest of the year falls below 2 per cent which regettably, seems unlikely, the Government and the unions apparently will not be able to reconcile their objectives. It is very important that they should. Does Mr Dolan want scenario B of the three scenarios presented to the Economic Summit? It seems to me to most closely approximate the ACTU's present demands. Scenario B, based on full catch-up after the wages pause, followed by quarterly indexation, was said in the Government's own scenario to produce little growth, inflation of over 13 per cent and unemployment rising over 12.5 per cent by 1985-86. Is that what we want? Is that what the ACTU wants ? If it continues to take the stand that it is taking now that is certainly what we are likely to get.

To reassure the unions the Government must, I believe, quite rapidly stop worrying about so-called spy flights over Tasmania, Federal Ministers' minor indiscretions over lunch and similar flotsam of politics and get down to the real problems of this country. There must be real incentives to increase productivity. We commend the ideas in former Senator Siddons's Industrial Democracy Bill. There must be a breakthrough into new and innovative areas of employment such as the energy industries. There must be a genuine effort to keep the costs of government down. I think the Government should address with the utmost seriousness the likely effects of higher taxation on employment and prosperity generally in this country. Labor complained that union militancy was the result of Mr Fraser's alleged refusal to consult with the unions. They have now been consulted to a hitherto unknown extent, and this is their answer.

There may be room for legitimate dispute about that-

We have reached the stage where one cannot believe what a leader of the Labor Party of this country puts forward to the people about his policies. We have seen what has happened in Victoria when Mr Cain became Premier of that State. He turned against all the promises he made during his campaign. We have seen what Mr Hawke has done since he became Prime Minister of this country. He has turned against all the promises of his campaign; he has turned against the consensus.
