SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the matter of public importance that has been proposed by the Opposition. Last week I had the privilege to represent my party in speaking to the matter of public importance concerning the Australian Broadcasting Commission. At the beginning of my speech I described that matter of public importance as a junk MPI. This matter qualifies for the same title. In fact, if this is the best that the Opposition can do, with its junk MPIs, it ought to go into business as Steptoe and Son. It is a bankrupt, threadbare proposal. There is not much for me to comment on after the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and Senator Robert Ray have debated the issue. But some remarks can be made to put the Government's point of view in summary form.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I make is that the Opposition cannot credibly enter this chamber or go to any other place in this country without escaping the responsibilities for its seven years in office. There has been a tendency in this debate to try to make it appear that the Fraser years never occurred and that that Government is not responsible for the high level of unemployment. It may well be a comment on the immaturity of the Opposition that it does not wish to face the responsibilities for its actions. I contrast the record of this Government with that of the Opposition. We have a comprehensive and equitable wages policy. The previous Government had no wages policy at all. Indeed, in January 1982 Mr Peacock, the present Leader of the Opposition, said:

Unless the Government adopts a coherent wages policy, unless it delivers its promise of tax cuts, unless it develops a working relationship between Government, employers and employees in industrial relations, there is little hope that inflation will be contained and the conditions set for growth in our economy.

Mr Peacock stated that the Government should adopt a coherent wages policy. Until the last election the Opposition did not have one and it still does not have one. On 5 May this year, a front page article in the Australian Financial Review, under the heading 'Opposition split on wages policy' stated:
The Federal Opposition yesterday decided that it had to strengthen its argument against the Government's wages policy by developing a policy of its own.

Although it has begun the first major Parliamentary session of the Labor Government by attacking the operation of the prices and incomes accord the Opposition is still divided between adherents of a decentralised system and those who would like to develop an alternative centralised approach to that of the Government.

The Opposition not only did not have a wages policy in January 1982; it still does not have one. It now pretends to attack this Government for a remark made by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions with regard to wages. I only wish that the Opposition would make up its mind on its position on wages.

Let us contrast its position with our position. We have a prices and incomes accord with the ACTU, an accord which is the basis of our approach to the economic well-being and recovery of this country. We held the National Economic Summit Conference which was notable for providing, in the beginning to all participants and now more widely to the community, all the relevant information necessary to know about the economy and to make informed choices for our future development. The communique which was issued after the end of the Summit provides a basis for unity of approach to wage fixation. We are now looking at a much more stable climate for industrial relations than under the Fraser Government.

Let us contrast that with the Opposition's period of office when there was confrontation and division. Indeed, at one stage during the last few years of the Fraser Government the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Viner, succeeded in alienating not only unions but also employers, both of whom attacked his handling of the industrial relations area. The then Government was divided amongst itself and against the industrial relations world . After indexation it pursued a policy which enabled sectional claims to evolve and which in fact encouraged a situation in which the strong got stronger and the weak and defenceless fell down in order to try to reduce real living standards in this country. That is the Opposition's record. Ours is one of order , consultation and rationality. Our target is half a million jobs over the next three years based on stable and progressive economic growth. The Opposition's record is half a million unemployed during the seven years of the Fraser Government and 271,000 people unemployed last year. That is the situation; and the blame for what the Opposition parties have done cannot be escaped and cannot be shrugged off. It cannot be made to appear that the seven years of Fraserism did not occur.

The Opposition's attack is upon the ACTU's wage claim. If that attack were to be credible, one would have thought that the Opposition would have started with an understanding of what the ACTU actually decided. That seems to me to be a relevant question. The Opposition has quoted a number of conservative newspaper editorials to justify its argument. The only comment I make about that is that the Opposition is conservative and the newspaper editorials are conservative, so it is not suprising that they both have the same view, which is a wrong view. Yesterday the ACTU made a decision on wages and salaries. It is perhaps useful to quote certain sections of that decision. I do not pretend to speak on behalf of the ACTU here, but let us look at its decision. It said:
The Executive notes the recognition given at the Summit to the legitimacy of the ALP/ACTU Prices-Incomes Accord.
The ACTU supports the accord. The second thing it said was:

It was further recognised at the Summit that the question of the timing and quantum of wage increases should be the subject of further discussion between the Parties at Conferences chaired by the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Sir John Moore.
The Government has attended various discussions, as have the ACTU and the employers-an observation of fact. The next thing the ACTU Executive said was:
This Executive resolves to pursue the ACTU claim for a return to a centralised wage fixation system consistent with the Prices-Incomes Accord.

It then said what its claim would be, and that is what struck a note of opposition from the Opposition. I hope that members of the Opposition listen because it is a salutory lesson in what in fact is really being said. I quote from the ACTU decision:
Implementation of the terms of the Accord in respect to wage rates will involve the ACTU seeking:
(A) an increase of 2.2 per cent to account for movements in prices as measured by the movements in the CPI for the eight capital cities for the March quarter of 1983.

The first point is that the ACTU is going to the Arbitration Commission-a body which has been venerated in this debate by the Opposition but which, during its period in government, it tried to undermine and destroy-to arbitrate for a wage increase based on cost of living adjustments, which case will not be heard until the middle of June this year. That is the claim of the ACTU. The second part of its claim is:
(B) Full cost of living adjustments on account of movements in the CPI on a quarterly basis for subsequent quarters.

The ACTU has made it clear that its argument is not so much with the amount of the claim but with the system by which wages are fixed. If there is a difference between the ACTU position and that of the Government, it is in that area. The Government has said that it is prepared to examine the possibility of indexation from the end of this year onwards but that, for the balance of this year, a 3 per cent to 4 per cent wage increase may be able to be accommodated. The ACTU is saying that it wants indexation based on the March quarter. That is the difference between the two positions. What has really been misrepresented is part (C) of the ACTU decision:
(C) The application of the 9.1 per cent to be pursued over a period of time consistent with the progress of economic recovery.

The 9.1 per cent is the rate of inflation from March to March. The ACTU is setting aside the cost of inflation to ordinary workers and wage earners over the last 12 months. It is accepting that that should be set aside and not pursued immediately. The big problem with the wage freeze which the previous Government invoked is that if things happen in Australia which happened during such freezes in other countries and if at the end of the freeze the Government has no policy on what should apply to the exit from the freeze, there will be yet another wages explosion consistent with the previous Government's view of cyclical fluctuations-explosion-recession followed by explosion-recession. The ACTU is saying that the exit from the freeze can be arbitrated, based on consumer price index increases, and that the CPI increases in the last 12 months can be set aside and pursued over time-these words are significant-consistent with the progress of economic recovery. I wish Senator Lewis was here to hear that, because he based a number of his arguments on the premise that it would not be consistent with economic recovery. That is what the ACTU said, and that is what the Opposition failed to attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not even read the decision.

—Members of the Opposition obviously do not know what is in it because they chose to believe what they read in the newspapers and attacked using straw arguments. The significant thing is that the ACTU has delineated what its claim will be when the Arbitration Commission meets in June. The Opposition, when it was the Government, sought a wage freeze for 12 months and, in response to the Government's arguments, the Arbitration Commission decided to hold a wage hearing decision in June. The ACTU will announce its position in June. If one looks at the fundamental questions of economic need at present, one sees that this Government has pursued a policy of saying that there is an absolute need for restraint. If one looks at the ACTU claim in the light of that call for restraint, one can see that a sacrifice is being made by wage and salary earners through the ACTU claim of a 9.1 per cent increase; that is to say ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia will be 9.1 per cent poorer in that a drop in real wages of that level will have occurred. That is the sacrifice of the union movement to try to get the economy of Australia moving again. However, under the prices and incomes policy, that sacrifice must be equitable. Therefore, the ACTU calls upon employers and governments-the other two tiers in the community; the other parts of the triumvirate-to exhibit equal sacrifice in an effort to lead to recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to me to be a lamentable problem in the Opposition's economics. When it talks of wages it has the one-dimensional view that wages are simply, only and nothing else but a cost. Of course, it is admitted that that is one effect of wages. The second effect of wages, the two-dimensional effect, is their effect as purchasing power in the pockets of consumers. If wages are held down, so is purchasing power. If purchasing power falls, so does net aggregate demand. I refer the Opposition to a survey conducted by the Confederation of Australian Industry in March 1983. I refer the Opposition to the question in that survey that was put to businesses throughout the country. The question was:
What is the most significant single factor affecting your company's profitability?

To that question, 90 per cent of the respondents to the Confederation of Australian Industry survey answered that the major factor was lack of orders. In other words, the major factor affecting business recovery according to business is lack of orders, that is, lack of demand. If demand is to be lifted, it presumes that people have purchasing power and can afford to buy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should we double wages then?

—I am talking about a responsible course, that is, to maintain some balance in the equation. Wages have fallen by 9.1 per cent in real terms over the last 12 months. That is a sacrifice that the wage and salary earners have made in this country in order to try to get the economy back on its feet. But if real demand was to fall below those figures the economy would be in a much more serious position. Perhaps the Opposition should come clean and say how far it wants wages to fall. Does it want Australians to live at Asian living standards, to compete with the Asian manufacturing industry, because that seems to me to be the final conclusion which the Opposition imputes from its own calculations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have only a few seconds remaining to speak. Perhaps I should use them to conclude that the Opposition is envious of the accord which the Australian Labor Government, under the premiership of Bob Hawke, has been able to achieve. It is jealous of our success in that area. The only way the Opposition can push its political goals and try to win office is to destroy the accord. I conclude by inviting the Opposition to forget its mean-minded, narrow attitude to development and appreciate that business, unions and others in the community are in accord and join the unity for the economic well-being of this country. That would be a very positive contribution it could make to the debate.

Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill continues the practice developed during the last Parliament of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament to make a large number of non-contentious amendments. Whilst in opposition we supported such legislation but were concerned that too often substantive amendments of major policy importance were tucked away in these Bills and the detail of such amendments was not readily available to the legal profession and the public.

On the former point I have approved procedures in relation to such Bills. The principal feature of those procedures is the criteria of the nature of matters which might be included in the Bill. I now inform the Parliament of those criteria:
(1) Only matters which genuinely deal with tidying up, correction and updating, routine administrative changes or are of minor policy significance, may be included.
(2) No matter that is contentious, or is closely related to a contentious matter, may be included.
(3) Matters that involve lengthy and complex drafting, particularly of a kind that may hold up the Bill, should generally not be included.
(4) Matters that involve substantial policy issues, including legal policy issues, should generally not be included.
(5) No matter that would constitute a change to the national companies and securities legislation may be included.
(6) No matter that imposes, abolishes or varies a tax or varies the incidence of a tax may be included.
(7) No matter involving an appropriation may be included except the repeal of a spent appropriation power.

I should, however, expressly draw the attention of the Senate to the proposals contained in this Bill regarding the furnishing and tabling of annual reports of departments and authorities. This is a matter with which the Parliament has been concerned for some time. In particular, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has made detailed recommendations for an annual reports Act containing detailed reporting criteria. More recently the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has commented adversely on the contents of annual reports.

Following interdepartmental committee consideration of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 has been drafted which would require all bodies which do not have a specific period within which to furnish a report to the Minister to do so within six months of the close of the reporting period. The Minister would then have 15 sitting days within which to table the report in the Parliament. Where the report is not furnished to the Minister within the six -month period a written explanation is required and an extension may be granted. Both the letter of explanation and the reasons for the grant of extension are to be tabled in the Parliament.

Those provisions, although not implementing the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee, are a marked improvement on the present situation. Accordingly, the Government has decided to go ahead with the proposed amendments as an interim measure. Consistent with its election commitment, as part of a wider review of its overall approach to statutory authorities, the Senate Standing Committee recommendations will be further considered by the Government as a matter of priority.

The proposed provisions of this Bill specifically exclude the need for compliance with them by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessments. The question of the tabling of annual reports by these bodies will be considered in the context of the larger question of the public accountability of the intelligence organisations. I commend the Bill to the Senate and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the supplementary statement referred to.
Leave granted.

If there were to be some substantive advantage achieved by the addition he proposes, so be it, but it seems clear to the Government that there is no such advantage and we would resist even the variation that the honourable senator proposes.

—The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has just said that the Government has an obligation to do all within its power. I suppose this is one of the reasons for the introduction of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, which is a move to overcome the terms of the Constitution regarding the rights of a State to look after its own properties. Could the Attorney-General explain to me what he understands by Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage? It says very clearly that in countries that have a system of federation the federal government, before introducing legislative measures, shall inform the competent authorities of the State of the provisions of the Convention and recommend their adoption. Article 34 clearly refers to a country such as Australia, which has a federation of States and a Constitution that forbids the Federal Government from interfering in the States' wishes in the methods they should adopt in using their own properties. It provides that the Federal Government may only inform the State authorities what it would like to happen. Can Senator Evans please let me know where in the Article, which applies to countries such as Australia, he finds an obligation to interfere with Tasmania?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that the honourable senator has rather misunderstood the force and effect of both the Australian Constitution and Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. The Australian Constitution does not in any way prohibit the Commonwealth from, as the honourable senator says, interfering with the States. It is a matter for the proper interpretation and construction of what the identified powers of the Commonwealth are.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are numerous powers-the corporations power, the trade and commerce power and those set out in most of the other placitums of section 51 of the Constitution-which clearly authorise the Commonwealth to do things, which the States might not like all that much, in the larger national interest. One of the powers the Commonwealth has under the Constitution is its power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth-that is, for the whole country-with respect to external affairs matters. Over the years that has been construed by the courts, as the honourable senator will possibly know, as empowering the Commonwealth to pass national laws which may have the effect of doing something the States might not be terrifically happy about in order to implement within Australia an international obligation that Australia, as a nation, has. There are ample precedents for this-for example, in the area of aviation going back to the 1930s. In the lifetime of the previous Government and before there was the Racial Discrimination Act, in regard to which litigation to preserve that reading of the Constitution was supported by the previous Government.

So there is ample precedent for the operation of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to that effect. It is against that background that the honourable senator and anyone else who is concerned about this matter should read Article 34 of the Convention. Article 34 refers to a Federal State which is a party to this World Heritage Convention and goes on to state:

(a) with regard to the provisions of this Convention, the implementation of which comes under the legal jurisdiction of the federal or central legislative power, the obligations of the federal or central government shall be the same as for those--

I interpolate countries which are not federal countries. So in cases where the power is available to the federal unit of government in a federal state, the obligation upon that federal government is the same as that for non-federal countries. The Article goes on to state, as the honourable senator read, that in cases where the implementation of a matter comes under the legal jurisdiction of individual constituent States there is the procedure which the honourable senator outlined. But she should not read Article 34 as excluding in any way the jurisdiction of the Australian Commonwealth Government and Parliament over these matters. By virtue of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution the Commonwealth does have the same power over these matters of international obligation as does the central government of another unitary country.

I appreciate that that is all a bit complicated and perhaps a bit difficult to grasp on the run, but there is power for the Federal Government to act. If there is not, that will be a matter for the High Court of Australia to tell us. Certainly this Government, like preceding governments, has proceeded on the assumption that there is this power to implement an international obligation. To the extent that there is that power to implement an international obligation, Article 34 entitles the Commonwealth Government to act as it is in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In introducing the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill the Government appears to rely very heavily on the external affairs power in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution. In support of this feeling I refer to section 100 of the Constitution, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade or commerce, abridge the right of a State or of the residents therein to the reasonable use of the waters of rivers for conservation or irrigation.
I would like the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to comment on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing first with Senator Watson's points, section 100 of the Constitution is perceived not to be relevant as a constitutional constraint here insofar as the Act in question will not be properly described as a law with respect to trade or commerce. It is only in relation to a law of trade or commerce that section 100 would appear to operate as a prohibition. For example, the invention of broadcasting is something that they did not anticipate . That in itself can never be a good, with respect, sensible ground to argue against the application of some constitutional provision. I turn to the question of what it means now and what it should mean given the larger interests of the nation as construed and interpreted through the Constitution by the High Court. If we are wrong, as Mr Ellicott once said, the High Court will undoubtedly tell us so.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the point made again by Senator Martin about whether or not the word ' property' should be specifically extended to include interest in land, I make the point again that that is simply redundant. The concept of property includes all the different kinds of interest in property which are just part of the law of property. They include lease interest, licence interest and other sorts of things which are in the nature of interests in land. Were this to be an improvement of the Bill and to make clear its application of course we would have no hesitation about acceding to that improvement and allowing the Bill to wend its way backwards and forwards across King's Hall in order to accommodate it. But given that it is redundant, given that it adds, in my considered view and that of the Parliamentary Counsel and the Government, nothing to the substance of the Bill we do not honestly want to waste time by adding additions of that kind.

The two most substantial objections were expressed by Senator Harradine. One of them, about the arguably unnecessary width of the Bill, was picked up and elaborated by Senator Martin. Let me return to Senator Harradine's concerns. He made the point that the expressions 'cultural heritage' and 'natural heritage' are very widely defined in the language of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, and indeed they are. But there is still , nonetheless, an overriding criterion to be satisfied for them properly to come within the scope of the Convention, and that is that the area, property, or interest in question be of outstanding universal value. Senator Harradine asked: 'Who is to construe that criterion? Who is to determine whether something is of outstanding value? Is it just a matter for the government of the day?' I answer in these terms: Not really; it is much more complex than that. A large number of hurdles have to be overcome before property can in fact come within the ambit of this legislation.

So far as that part of clause 3 which provides for submission to the World Heritage Committee as a vehicle for gaining recognition for the property in question is concerned, it is the case that we are talking here about a mere nomination; we are not talking about a stage of acceptance as appropriately part of the World Heritage List having been reached. But there is a real disincentive on any nation submitting a Luna Park, a municipal lavatory or some other bizarre item of purported cultural heritage. I do not want to be taken as suggesting that neither Luna Park nor some appropriately decorated municipal lavatory might not ultimately come within this description. But let us assume the submission of some piece of property that manifestly on any view does not come within that description, here and now at least. There would be a real lack of credibility involved in a nation going through the business of purporting to submit to a very august world body some such piece of property as satisfying this description. Quite an elaborate procedure has to be followed in putting in a submission to the inventory operated by the World Heritage Committee. A series of rules and procedures have to be satisfied. Any nation which did that would simply make a laughing stock of itself in the international community. I suggest to the Committee that that point operates as a real disincentive against that part of the clause being cavalierly misused.

As to the possibility of the Commonwealth simply regulating a piece of property into this status unilaterally, again I point to the hurdle that the Commonwealth would have to overcome, that is, the disallowance procedures for any such regulation. Certainly, as the Senate is presently constituted and as, regrettably, is seems likely to be constituted for some considerable time yet, the Commonwealth would have great difficulty, obviously, in again cavalierly misusing the regulation provision in order to identify as a cultural heritage or natural heritage some piece of property which manifestly was not. Again, so far as any means of establishing property as identified property is concerned, it still remains a matter for the High Court, if the external affairs power provisions of this Bill are being relied on, to determine ultimately whether the property in question satisfies the description as being of universal value. Unless it is of universal value and the High Court can be so persuaded by evidence on affidavit and so on, the High Court will say: 'This is just not a genuine exercise of the external affairs power. You are not here meeting an international obligation to protect property of this description. This is a device. This is a sham.' This, of course, is part of the argument that will be conducted before the High Court in the Tasmanian case.

I suggest to honourable senators that, although the language is very wide, nonetheless a series of hurdles have to be overcome. I remind honourable senators in this context that, before the Bill actually bites on any State or Territory government to stop it doing something, a series of procedural hurdles have to be satisfied. The property has to be identified as 'identified property' by the various means I have been talking about. Then one has to have a proclamation by the Governor-General-in-Council that the property in question, in the language of the Bill, is being or is likely to be damaged or destroyed. That proclamation is the subject of disallowance in the Parliament if it is cavalierly employed. Then of course one has to have an actual prohibition set in train by the government of the day pursuant to that proclamation. If that prohibition is cavalier and not designed genuinely to protect or to conserve the property in question, under the Bill as it stands all sorts of people have a right of standing to challenge the lawfulness, under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, of the exercise of that power.

Again, I am sorry to bore any honourable senators with this detail but it is necessary to appreciate the technical effect of the Bill. I suggest that a discussion of this kind is entirely appropriate for the Committee stage and much to be preferred to some of the more extravagant oratory that we have had in the past. I make no reference to Senator Walters. I saw her lurch to her feet as I uttered that phrase.

The final comment I wish to make is an attempt to answer the more general point which both Senator Harradine and Senator Martin made. They argue: 'Okay. Take into account all those points and those hurdles and limitations, but is not the Bill nonetheless still much wider than it needs to be to deal with the situation of South West Tasmania?' In a sense, yes, it is. It is much wider than it needs to be simply to deal with South West Tasmania. But there are two reasons why the Bill is as potentially wide as it is. The first reason is that so far as we are aware there are no items of outstanding international importance, either by way of cultural heritage or natural heritage, that are now immediately under threat. But that is not to say that they will not be under threat at some relatively immediate time in the future. It is wholly desirable to have in place the machinery and mechanism by which such threats can be dealt with, should they arise.

Should the Queensland Government, in breach of all its undertakings and so on, decide over the next Christmas recess to embark immediately on some oil drilling exercise on the Great Barrier Reef, it would be very important and useful indeed to have this kind of legislative machinery in place so that the Government could very quickly move into operation to block or to cut off such a potentially devastating threat to that international property. That is the first desire- simply to have machinery in place. The second reason is that it is necessary to have a Bill expressed this widely if we are genuinely to satisfy our international obligations under the international Convention. The international Convention does not commit us simply to an obligation to defend South West Tasmania. The international Convention commits us to the defence of any property in Australia which satisfies the description in the Convention as being of outstanding universal value, either culturally or by way of the natural heritage . That is our international obligation.

If we are to satisify that international obligation, we have to legislate in the terms covered by the parameters of the Convention. Of course, the incidental advantage of doing so is not only to be able to hold our head up internationally if challenged on this point but also to ensure-this is the further reason it becomes relevant-the survival of the Bill under constitutional attack in the High Court. It is only by expressing it in general terms and not in narrow, discriminatory terms against South West Tasmania that we believe the chances of the Bill's survival, insofar as it depends upon the external affairs power, can be maximised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) referred, I presume not derogatorily, to Justice Murphy and his far-reaching and radical decisions.

We cannot by legislation turn the Northern Territory into a State and I do not suggest that that is desirable at the moment, for a range of reasons. However, to protect that position that the Northern Territory and its Government have earned I have moved my amendment.

The second aspect of the amendment is that under the compensation provisions, if they stand as printed, the Premiers of States have certain rights to appoint members to commissions determining compensation, and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, if there is an issue in relation to compensation in the Territory, does not have the right to appoint people to such commissions. Clause 6 is, of course, the crux of this Bill. The issue is not whether there should be a dam in South West Tasmania; it is whether we are to have the usage of the external affairs power of the Constitution in such a way that we might as well forget about Federation. During the debate a number of--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't mean that; come on!
—Senator, you have lots of turns. I am familiar with your point of view. That is not going to stop you expressing it. You may be familiar with mine. I am going to express it.
—Well, why don't you give your own view and not someone else's?

—I am sorry I called a division, Madam Chairman. It seems to have brought into the chamber all sorts of people who are not really interested in the Bill. Section 51 of the Constitution allows the Parliament, subject to the Constitution, to have power to make laws for the 'peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth' with respect to external affairs; and other powers are delineated. This clause of the Bill reaches out to take in all the powers of the Constitution that this Government has been able to think of to make this Bill legitimate. Of course, the High Court will determine whether the Bill is legitimate in the end. But I say to the Government that it has succumbed to a temptation which it may well regret in the end. I also say to the Government that I am sure it is aware that it is not the first government that has had that temptation. It is just the first to have grabbed at the opportunity as fully as this clause and the provisions of this Bill provide.

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-section (2) of the Bill which the Opposition would have deleted and replaced provides a number of heads of power under which the Commonwealth is proceeding or attempting to proceed, not the least significant of which is that in paragraph (e), that is, the nationhood power. The appeal to heritage that is distinctive of the Australian nation has nothing to do with the World Heritage Convention and nothing to do with what the Government says are our obligations under international agreements, controversial as those agreements are or as the Government's interpretation of our obligations under those agreements are. Clause 6, sub-section (2) states that proclamations may be made in relation to certain property on the basis of an international obligation, whether by reason of the Convention or otherwise. A little while ago Senator Walters referred to a view that has been expressed by Dr Klugman, a member of the Government, a view that was referred to in the second reading debate here and in the other place. The dangers of basing on this what is really domestic policy should be very obvious. The dangers should be obvious to the Australian Labor Party whether in Government or in Opposition.

I agree that the matter whether a dam is built in South West Tasmania is a very serious one. The Fraser Government went to quite extraordinary lengths to try to persuade the Tasmanian Government not to go ahead with the construction of that dam. What we were not prepared to do in Government was to move on the external affairs power so that a State government could be told whether it could build a dam and how it was to generate its power. Distressing as the issue is, it is a matter that should have been negotiated, and negotiated fully. I am not going to traverse the entire argument of what the Hawke Government did or did not do. However, I assert that its record on this matter is very poor indeed. I do not think anyone is satisfied that the Hawke Government really tried to negotiate with the Tasmanian Government. On the contrary, after coming to government the Australian Labor Party moved very quickly to do anything but negotiate and to take a confrontationist attitude.

The Opposition claims that Australia has certain responsibilities under its international agreements. I say to the Government that, in a democracy, its first responsibility is to the nation within its borders. The Government has the responsibility to the Constitution, and to constitutional arrangements of powers and to what people's expectations are under the Constitution. The laws should not be made by the High Court. The fact is that the High Court interprets the law from time to time. That has resulted in the Commonwealth being ruled to have certain powers that some people may have believed it did not have. But they are trivial in comparison with the attempt that the Government makes on this occasion. If that attempt is successful, frankly, the sky is the limit in relation to Commonwealth Government powers-the Government is attempting, through writing a Bill very persuasively, to bring the High Court to the point of view that it ought to take this action in relation to something that has always been regarded as a State power and responsibility.

The fact is that nobody would have thought until very recently that a Commonwealth government would have attempted to legislate on the matter of the building of a dam or the generation of power under this head of power in the Constitution. It may be that the High Court will rule in the Government's favour on this case but if it does the Government will know that it has achieved that power through a device of wording in this clause which has nothing whatsoever to do with what the people of Australia want to see happen to their Constitution, and it is their Constitution.

Power in Australia does not belong to the Commonwealth Government or the State governments. Power belongs to the people of Australia because they determine what power a Commonwealth or a State government will have. The people approved a Constitution. They have had several opportunities to change the Constitution. Sometimes they have agreed to a changing of the Constitution, but sometimes they have said: 'No, that is your suggestion, but this is our decision'. They have reasserted that the distribution of power and who may exercise it belongs to them. So, the Constitution belongs to the people, not to the High Court, not to the Attorneys-General, not to lawyers with their fancy arguments that can go on for hours and not, indeed, to the politicians with their fancy arguments that can also go on for hours on occasions-but only when the occasion merits, of course. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), the Government and, I think , the High Court, would know that, if a proposal was put to the people of Australia that power be so rearranged under section 51 of the Constitution that a Commonwealth Government was to have the power to decide who was to build dams and generate power, if it was going to decide whether on a piece of land in a State a tree could be cut down, I am sure that all of the powers and other aspects that are detailed under this Bill would not be agreed to by the people.

In the second reading debate, I made reference to an editorial in the Australian Financial Review. That editorial and my argument on it were picked up by Senator Coates and presented quite wrongly. The argument in that editorial- the point which I put to the Government now-was that for all the Government's bleating on certain matters after the Constitutional Convention, this Bill, which raises one of the strongest points at issue under our Constitution since Federation, was not put to the Constitutional Convention. Indeed the power transfer that this Bill represents was not put by the Government to the Constitutional Convention. The Government could have sought an opinion, but it knows very well that it would not even have had its Labor Caucus operating in that Constitutional Convention if it had sought to take to the central Government the sort of power that this Bill and this clause in particular seek to take to the central Government.

The Attorney-General ought to address himself to the point that has been raised again and again, from within his party and outside his party. What is the limit of those international conventions and treaties if this provision is to be acted upon? We are signatories and have been signatories in good faith to a number of United Nations international conventions. I, along with other members of the Opposition, am urging the ratification of another convention. But it is not my intention that, in so doing, certain powers be taken away from State governments , which is a potential if the Attorney means to proceed in this way. I ask the Attorney: What is his intention? What is his Government's intention in relation to those international conventions of the same kind as this to which we have been signatories? Does he intend to use them, or would he use them in such a way in the future to override what have been considered to be the powers of the States in the past if a State government did something that this Government did not like, or if a State government did something that some pressure group did not like and that pressure group was in a position to bring some sort of pressure to bear on the Government? What is his intention in relation to those conventions?

Is this the first step? If it is not, and this is a once-off measure, I ask: Why? What is so different about the arguments that can be advanced for this specific case and the just as persuasive, just as emotive and just as worthy arguments that can be advanced in other cases under other conventions? I would like to know the criteria that this Government applies and the criteria that the Attorney-General will apply and recommend to his Government in the future.

First of all, the land or property in question has to satisfy the description of 'identified property'. To satisfy the description of 'identified property', it cannot be just any old property; it has to be property which fits the description of being of outstanding universal value within the meaning of the language of that international convention and which is identified as such either by Commonwealth regulation, which is subject to disallowance, or by being nominated through the international procedure, which is a very complex procedure and in which the credibility of a country is at risk if it does otherwise than nominate property which properly satisfies that description. That is the first thing. There has to be identified property and it has to satisfy those criteria.

The second thing that has to happen is that there has to be a proclamation by the Governor-General that the property in question is at risk in some way, is in danger of being destroyed or damaged by virtue obviously of the inability or unwillingness of the State or Territory in question to move for the defence of the area. That is the precondition, and the only precondition, on which such a proclamation can operate; and that proclamation as we have seen is subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament. Even then nothing happens until such time as the Government of the day further moves specifically under a further clause to actually prohibit something being done. If that prohibition is undertaken for the wrong sorts of reasons which do not have relevance to the protection or conservation of the property, then all sorts of people and organisations have standing under the operation of this legislation to challenge the exercise of that power. The legislation needs to be wide to satisfy our international obligations under the Convention, not to mention our obligations to the Australian people and future generations of Australians. Despite its potentially wide reach, it has to satisfy in practice a whole series of hurdles before it actually bites or interferes with anybody. It operates against the wishes of a State only in those circumstances in which the Commonwealth can satisfy the ultimate tribunal, the High Court, that the property in question is in jeopardy. I think that has to be appreciated. This is the context in which we are talking. It is not that wide-ranging.

The reason for the drafting of sub-paragraphs (a) to (d) is simply to deal with the various formulations of the external affairs power that have been enunciated by different judges of the High Court over a considerable period. Some judges have given some indication of the way in which they have expressed the operation of the external affairs power. Some judges have put it that what might be crucial is the actual participation in the State by the State in the process of creating the external obligation. That is the reason for the presence in the Bill of sub- paragraph (a). As to Senator Harradine's concerns about sub-paragraph (a) and its purported retrospectivity, I indicate to him that this does not just apply to Tasmania. The language of sub-paragraph (a) applies equally to the world heritage property in the Great Barrier Reef, the Willandra Lakes in New South Wales and also Lord Howe Island, because it was only the Government in each of those cases that approved the nomination. It was not in fact the State Parliament. SPEECH.PARA: Each of sub-paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) is expressed in language which reflects the differing degrees of width that High Court judges have been willing to ascribe to the external affairs power. Sub-paragraph (b) refers to protection as a matter of international obligation, whether by reason of the Convention or otherwise. That is an endeavour to pick up the formula enunciated by those judges who say that what matters is the fact that there is some kind of international obligation to which Australia is a party, whether that obligation is clearly expressed in the form of some treaty obligation, or whether, rather, it is simply there as a matter of international common law, as it were, or as a matter of international comity. Various levels and degrees of obligation can be identified in appropriate cases.

Sub-paragraph (c) focuses specifically on the question of Australia's involvement in treaty obligations with one or more other countries. It focuses on the view that some judges have that the external affairs power is attracted simply by virtue of Australia being party to a proper international treaty. I repeat here that, when we are talking about treaties, we are not simply talking about treaties entered into for the deliberate, contrived purpose of attracting the external affairs power. We are talking-and every judge who has ever passed judgement upon this issue has made the distinction clear-about the genuine treaties which concern matters that are, properly speaking, the subject of international diplomatic discourse. That is what sub-paragraph (c) is about.

Sub-paragraph (d) is another variation on those themes. What constitutes international concern is a matter for the High Court to determine, having regard to the evidence available to the High Court by way of affidavit or otherwise, using its own judgment as to what sort of subject matter is so much in the international domain that it is legitimate to say that Australia has an international obligation with respect to it.

I refer, as I have on a number of occasions, to what Mr Ellicott, the former Attorney-General, said, when he spoke in 1974 in the Parliament to the Whitlam Goverment's National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Bill, which relied in part on this concept of an implied or inherent nationhood power. The boundaries or dimensions of that power, as set out in sub-paragraph (e) of this Bill, and in similar terms in the National Parks and Wildlife Bill, are unclear and uncertain. . . . uncertainty as to the extent of constitutional power never of itself be a reason for opposing an otherwise worthwhile legislative exercise of power;
nor should it prevent a government, properly advised, treading where angels of constitutional probity have formerly feared to tread. The High Court, as we know , will readily give us the answer-

To anyone here tonight, or during the course of the afternoon, who has been minded to be upset about the Commonwealth's reliance on either the external affairs power or the nationhood power, I say that what they are demonstrating is a profound lack of respect for and confidence in the High Court. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution relates to clause 9 (1) and (2), clause 12 (1) and clause 13 (1). Clause 13 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: In determining whether or not to give a consent pursuant to section 9 in relation to any property to which that section applies, the Minister shall have regard only to the protection, conservation and presentation, within the meaning of the Convention, of the property.

I have looked at the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage which appears in the Schedule and which is referred to in a number of the articles-for example, Article 5 (d) and (e) and Article 23. What is the meaning of 'presentation' in clause 13 (1)? Could it be taken to mean that it refers to accessibility by the public? What, in fact, does that word mean?

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, 'presentation' means exactly that. Senator Harradine has identified the concept correctly. That term means that whereas it may not be legitimate to build a road, to establish a viewing point or to do something of that kind in relation to a cultural site if one had regard only to the protection or conservation of the property itself, if one has regard to the presentation of the property-that is, the physical access of people to it to be able to enjoy it to the maximum-it becomes defensible to erect the work, the access road or whatever is in question. That concept has particular relevance in the context of South West Tasmania, for example. That would mean that it is entirely consistent with the operation of this legislation for the Minister to have regard to the desirability of tourist roads being built in certain areas of the wilderness-for example, to enable access of people in order to enjoy the pleasures that the wilderness represents. On the other hand, perhaps an extremely hard-line conservationist position would have it that only those armed with boots and dangling corks and with strong legs should be able to enjoy the area in question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That raises the matter I raised in the second reading debate as to the validity of the debate on the Tasmanian wilderness. SPEECH.PARA: For example, leaving South West Tasmania out of it altogether, if there were an identified property and it was for the common good that some safety measure be installed in that area for persons either going to or coming from the area, would that not be a relevant consideration in determining to give consent or is the Minister too constrained by the criteria set down in clause 13 (1)? It refers to zoning and management plans in federal legislation. I have made this point before and I will make it again. I am suggesting that I am concerned to see no reference to State management plans under State legislation in respect of identified properties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first point raised, technically speaking the Minister is only supposed to have regard to protection, conservation and presentation issues. That means that someone who believes that the Minister has not had regard to those criteria can, under the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, seek a review of his decision on the ground that it is unlawful because it has not been made by reference to those criteria. One can say in that respect only that courts would not, I believe, in the sort of situation Senator Harradine has raised in which there is some overriding safety consideration in issue, find themselves absurdly constrained by those criteria. There is always an overriding public interest criteria which courts feel able to apply in those sorts of situations. I am sure that the concepts inherent in that area are broadly flexible enough to accommodate Senator Harradine's concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is drafted as it is because we wanted to indicate at least the direction to which the court ought to have regard in adjudicating on these issues and also because, of course, we wanted to adhere as closely as possible to the terms of the international Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and National Heritage which, in fact, uses that formula. But I do not think it is reasonable to assume that the court would be absurdly constrained in its application of those considerations.

As to the possibility of State plans of management being satisfactory under this legislation even though they are not recognised specifically by it, I think the point to be made is simply that if it is the case that some legitimate State plan of management is in operation in relation to a heritage-type area and that State plan of management is bona fide and one which is directed to the preservation for use and enjoyment of the area in question, it is hardly likely that that area would satisfy the description of being property which is being damaged or destroyed or is likely to be damaged or destroyed within the meaning of the trigger sections of this Bill. So although there is no explicit provision for an automatic exemption simply by virtue of the existence of something purporting to be a State plan of management, if it is a fair dinkum plan of management one would believe that the Bill could have no application to the area in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 9 (1) (h). I gather this is an area that is left open for any future legislation, regulation or whatever the Government thinks might be necessary in the future. Is that the meaning of that paragraph?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

Clause 14 (Enforcement).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 8, clause 14, sub-clause (1), line 25, leave out 'The High Court or'.
(6) Page 8, clause 14, sub-clause (2), lines 28 and 29, leave out the 'the High Court or'.
(7) Page 8, clause 14, sub-clause (2), line 30, leave out 'the High Court or' and ', as the case may be'.

The amendments all relate to the same point. The purpose of the amendments is to ensure that the judicial body which is given the power to administer the Act is the Federal Court of Australia and not the High Court of Australia. For example, clause 14 (1) states:

The High Court or the Federal Court may, on the application of the Attorney- General or of an interested person, grant an injunction restraining a person from doing an act that is unlawful by virtue of section 9, 10 or 11.

Clauses 9, 10 and 11 on which we have had brief debate, define the unlawful acts . Clause 9 states what things cannot be done, such as carrying out excavation works, carrying out operations, erecting a building, damaging a building, killing or damaging trees, constructing any roads or vehicular tracks, using explosives and 'if an act is prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph' and so on. That clause is very detailed in relation to the acts that are described as unlawful under this Bill. They are essentially questions of fact. The High Court is better suited to determine appeals and state principles in relation to acts rather than determine questions of fact. We believe that the Federal Court should be the court that is named here as the appropriate court. Of course that in no way affects anyone's right of appeal to the High Court which will always stand. The effect of questions of fact going to the High Court rather than the Federal Court will be, firstly, to overburden the High Court and, secondly, to very substantially slow down the process of receiving determinations and decisions on matters of fact. People are entitled to as speedy a resolution of their legal actions as possible and the Federal Court is equipped and in a position to give far speedier resolutions of cases such as those which come under clauses 9, 10 and 11 than is the High Court. Further on in our amendments we raised the same issue in relation to clause 17, for example. I am not foreshadowing debate on clause 17 but the issues remain the same. As a matter of principle we think that it is unreasonable in these two clauses to specify the High Court. We believe the more appropriate court is the Federal Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain why the High Court of Australia is given original jurisdiction here. It is largely connected with the reference that appears in clause 17 to which the honourable senator refers. An issue which may arise about whether a particular exercise by the Commonwealth of its power under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill amounts to an acquisition of land within the meaning of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution is a matter which can ultimately be properly resolved only by the High Court. If there is an argument about whether something amounts to an acquisition-that has to take place in the High Court-it would seem appropriate that if the matter is of sufficient size and importance to justify the High Court's attention, the High Court should also have the capacity to deal with the rest of the matter. Of course the High Court already has original jurisdiction in those matters where the Commonwealth is a party. As a result one would imagine that it would be appropriate for other parties to initiate litigation against the Commonwealth in the High Court because the matter will end up there sooner of later. Rather than having to go through some intermediate step it would seem appropriate that the option at least be available to start the action there.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not suggest that Senator Martin's amendment is entirely without merit. I can understand the point that she is making but equally I ask her to take on board the fact that there are circumstances in which it is appropriate that the High Court have original jurisdiction. The matter is expressed in the alternative. It does not have to begin in the High Court; it can start in the Federal Court. Should the matter be essentially trivial in its significance, or in terms of the monetary values and so on that are involved, of course it is always open for the High Court to remit the matter back to another court which has jurisdiction in it, in this case the Federal Court. Although reasonable men and women-indeed even reasonable honourable senators-may differ about the utility of this provision, it is not one that ought to detain us, and I suggest that accordingly we do not amend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take exception to the concluding remarks of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). If the issue is one worth debating it is one that ought to detain us. I am getting irritated by suggestions such as that made earlier when Senator Lewis raised a point that he is perfectly entitled to raise that time is being wasted. It is nothing of the sort. Important matters are at stake and I appreciate such explanations as the Attorney-General gives but I point out that he has talked more than anybody else in the debate this evening and it is not--
—Be fair; I am just trying to help.

—I have said that I appreciate the Minister's help. I do not even mind if it is lengthy. But the Minister should not mind if other honourable senators put their point of view that is perfectly legitimate in relation to the Bill. I reiterate that clause 14 (1) relates to the granting of an injunction restraining a person from doing an act that is unlawful by virtue of clauses 9, 10 or 11. It seems to me that that is a very straightforward issue. Sub-section (2) of section 14 refers to an application which has been made for an injunction restraining a person from doing an act. I do not see why we retain this emphasis on the High Court of Australia. I have said that the issue also arises in relation to clause 17 which we will come to later in greater detail. I repeat- the Attorney-General did not negate this-that there is always the right of appeal from a decision of the Federal Court of Australia to the High Court. The Federal Court determines matters on the basis of fact and if someone believes that the fact has been wrongly stated the High Court can apply to the principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why force a litigant to go through two steps if it is possible to allow him to go to one?

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of the matter is that under clause 14 it is not only the Commonwealth that is likely to be a party; other persons have standing to sue in relation to these matters. The matter may be one of very great magnitude-very great importance-which clearly will not finish at the level of the Federal Court of Australia and clearly will be litigated up to the High Court of Australia if one of the party gets an adverse response. It is simply an enabling provision to ensure that, in a matter of sufficient magnitude, parties are not put to the expense of going through dual stages where it is appropriate that they leap immediately to the highest.

If the matter is trivial and if it is not one that the High Court wants to waste its time on, I can assure the honourable senator that the High Court, notwithstanding that it is vested with original jurisdiction under this clause, retains the power to remit the matter back to a junior court-the Federal Court- and would undoubtedly exercise that power in an appropriate case if it thought that its resources were being misused, just as at the moment, for example, the High Court has the constitutional jurisdiction to deal with any matter that arises between residents of different States. So if there is a motor car accident involving absolutely no questions of law of any significance and maybe only quite trivial questions of damages, technically the High Court has jurisdiction to deal with that. But the High Court has made it very clear for a number of decades now that, should anyone have the temerity to approach it seeking the exercise of its jurisdiction in such a matter which is essentially trivial, the High Court will not have a bar of it and it will be sent back to another court accordingly. It is an enabling provision. I am not trying to be offensive in any way in suggesting that we do not waste time on this matter. I am simply saying that I do not think that it in any way inhibits the effective operation of this legislation. Accordingly, objections to the clause in this form ought not to be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has not given an example. I reiterate: The clause relates to the granting of an injunction. It is standard in a number of Acts to provide that the court in the first instance is the Federal Court, which does not take away from appeals going to the High Court, I reiterate. We are not trying to do something to this Bill that is not contained in many other Acts of the Parliament. It might have helped if the Attorney-General, instead of flinging himself around in exasperation, had given an example that explained his case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give one example: If one has a case like the South West wilderness in which some hundreds of millions of dollars are potentially involved in litigation, it would not seem to the point to require a non-Commonwealth litigant to start his case in a matter of that magnitiude in a court where obviously it will not finish.

Clause 17 (Compensation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 10, clause 17, sub-clause (1), definition of 'acquisition of property' , line 27, at end of definition, add, 'as extended by sub-section 3A'.
(9) Page 11, clause 17, after sub-clause (3), insert the following new sub- clause:

'(3A) For the purposes of sub-section (3) property shall be deemed to have been acquired from a person in accordance with the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 to the extent that its use or its enjoyment by a person has been affected by the operation of this Act or the Regulations.'.
(10) Page 11, clause 17, sub-clause (4), line 11, leave out 'High Court', insert 'Federal Court'.
(11) Page 11, clause 17, Paragraph (6) (b), line 23, leave out 'High Court', insert 'Federal Court'.
(12) Page 11, clause 17, sub-clause (6), lines 28 and 29, leave out all words after 'agreement', insert:
'the Commonwealth is liable to pay such compensation as is deternmined by the Federal Court to be fair and just'.
(13) Pages 11 and 12, clause 17, sub-clause (7), line 43 (page 11), to line 2 ( page 12), leave out all words after 'shall', insert:
'determine the compensation that he considers to be fair and just in respect of the acquisition not later than 14 days after the said 6 months period expires'.
(14) Page 12, clause 17, sub-clauses (8) and (9), lines 3 to 23, leave out sub- clauses, insert the following sub-clause:

'(8) Interest shall be payable on the amount of compensation determined by the Governor-General or the Federal Court (as the case may require), such interest to be calculated from the date of the acquisition up to and including the date of payment at a rate of interest which is fair and just in the circumstances.'.
(15) Page 13, clause 17, sub-clause (14) and (15), lines 9 to 26, leave out the sub-clauses insert the following sub-clause:

'(14) Where the operation of this Act or of the Regulations has resulted in or is taken to have resulted in an acquisition of property from a person and the person considers that the compensation determined by the Governor-General is not fair and just, the Federal Court may, on the application of the person, determine the compensation that is fair and just in respect of the acquisition'.

The issue arises whether the freezing of the use of land by proclamation under the legislation would amount to an acquisition of property. To clarify that point we have moved two amendments, the first one, No. (8), relating to the second and the second, No. (9), being the critical one, by inserting a new sub- clause (3A) into clause 17 to read:

For the purposes of sub-section (3) property shall be deemed to have been acquired from a person in accordance with the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 to the extent that its use or its enjoyment by a person has been affected by the operation of this Act or the Regulations.

There is no practical difference between a government acquiring land and depriving an owner of the use of the land and the government ordering that no use can be made of the land. We believe that the Lands Acquisition Act ought to apply, and that property that the Commonwealth takes action on under this clause ought to be deemed to have been acquired so that the Lands Acquisitions Act can apply. There will be further debate on the other amendments as to the details of compensation, but I mention these two amendments in the first series of amendments that I have moved and in which the Opposition has embodied its fundamental opposition to the attitude towards the acquisition of land and compensation for that acquisition under this Act. The provisions of the Lands Acquisitions Act, we believe, are appropriate. We also believe that they are preferable to the procedure that is outlined in the Bill.

I referred earlier in the debate to the Attorney-General's reply in the second reading debate last night. He made a number of statements in relation to acquisition of land and what the Government perceives to be acquisition of land specifically in relation to South West Tasmania and relevant matters relating to compensation. We seek through these amendments to establish the principle that to act in relation to the property in the way in which the Commonwealth intends to under this Bill amounts to acquisition, should be recognised as such, and should follow the principles of land acquisition which have been followed by the Commonwealth for a long time now, and that is as outlined in the Lands Acquisition Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to repeat at any length what I said last night but I think it ought to be said at the outset of this debate on the compensation clause of this Bill that what the Bill is about is basically not the acquisition of land at all. Certainly there is no explicit provision entitling the Commonwealth, pursuant to this Bill, to acquire land. If the Commonwealth is to acquire land directly and deliberately, no doubt it will do so under the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill and clause 17 simply contain a kind of fail safe mechanism to ensure that, should the interference with the use and enjoyment of the land in question be of such magnitude that the courts are minded to find that it amounts to acquisition, there are appropriate provisions in the specific terms of the Bill to enable the compensation to be determined, having regard of course to the constitutional requirement in section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution that where there is a compulsory acquisition of land by the Commonwealth just terms be given for it. It is in that context, and in that context alone, that the Bill refers to acquisition and to compensation. I really do try to make it clear at the outset that, if the Commonwealth is embarking on a deliberate acquisition exercise, this is not the provision that will apply on their face; it will be the provisions in other existing Commonwealth legislation.

Be that as it may, let us come to deal with the terms of the clause as they do in fact stand. What we have in this amendment-I will not canvass the other amendments that have been moved-is a really quite extraordinary clause which I cannot believe Senator Martin or her advisers in the other place have seriously thought through. What it says is that property shall be deemed to have been acquired from a person in accordance with the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act to the extent that its use or enjoyment by a person has been affected by the operation of this Act. Use and enjoyment can be affected in all sorts of ways with all sorts of degrees of significance. It may be, for example, in respect of some area of outstanding natural beauty that a State electricity commission wants to put a series of pylons across it. By virtue of the operation of this Act the Commonwealth could direct that the pylons not be put through that corner of the land in question but rather be re-routed-at a cost of some dollars, but that is all. There is no interference other than that with the use or enjoyment of the land in question.

The way this clause is framed, that would be deemed to be an acquisition of the land in question and the Commonwealth would be up for the full cost of such an acquisition as determined by the criteria in the Lands Acquisition Act. Is that fair? Is that a reasonable imposition on the Commonwealth Treasury? Take again some area of cultural heritage more than natural heritage like, say, on Lord Howe Island. Let us assume that we have a built-up area that the nation regards as an area of outstanding universal value and the Commonwealth wants to stop renovations or extensions being undertaken to the buildings in question. Say it insists on retaining a two-storey height limit and will not let the owner of a small guest house add another storey. That is obviously an interference in the use and enjoyment by that person of the property in question. Are we as a result of this provision to have an automatic deeming that thereby the Commonwealth is acquiring that property in question and therefore has to fork out the full amount?

It may be that some compensation is appropriate for the interference involved; that is something that can be determined by reference to other criteria. It seems to me in all seriousness to be an utterly misconceived amendment. For those reasons, quite apart from the more basic reason-that the thrust of these compensation provisions is quite different from that which seems to be believed- I have specifically indicated that it seems to me the amendment must be resisted .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I find the view of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) on this matter passing strange. It seems to me that it does not really make a great deal of difference if what is found by a court to be an acquisition by reason of action under this legislation is not intended to be an acquisition. It is right that the Government should provide in the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill for a situation where the action is found to be an acquisition. If a person then suffers loss of use or enjoyment and so forth, he has suffered it just as greatly whether or not the Government intends it to be an acquisition or whether in fact it is just an acquisition by reason of the Constitution. I find the Attorney's first point, therefore, very curious indeed. I do not see that there is any real distinction and I think the people have the same suffering and the same entitlement to just terms if it comes in that way as if it comes from the full intention of the Commonwealth to acquire.

SPEECH.PARA: Nor did I find the rest of the argument convincing. It seems to me that this amendment, if it is carried, must be tied with sub-clause (3) and paragraph (a) of that sub-clause. I would have thought that if a person makes a claim and it is found, then he ought to have the right and privileges which the Lands Acquisition Act has given to people who have had land acquired over many years. I must say that I do not find the argument convincing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much interference with use amounts to an acquisition? Is any interference at all to be construed as an acquisition? That is what your new paragraph 3 (a) says. That is absurd.
—To the extent that it is interfered with-
—That is what mine says, not what yours says.
—That is what it does say-to the extent that use and enjoyment by a person have been affected-
—Have been affected, not have been affected enormously, gigantically or impossibly but have been affected.
—It might be affected only by a small amount and so it might be small compensation. I still think the right should exist under the Lands Acquisition Act to enjoy those benefits.

—The Australian Democrats support the Government on this matter. This amendment has caused us some concern and we have looked at it with great care. Indeed, the question of Lord Howe Island and the analogy that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) made had occurred to us also. Suppose somebody there has a two-storey guest house, the business is operating satisfactorily and the owner wants to add to it but is prevented from doing so. The fact that he is not allowed to do so does not affect his present income; nor can any active acquisition be justified. Acquisition is not a thing that can be had in small degrees; one either acquires something or does not acquire it. It does not make sense to us at all. There needs to be a much more flexible area of compensation, and it would be very damaging to people if there were not a flexible area of compensation. The Opposition amendment could create legal difficulties which might be of great embarrassment to people and of difficulty to them if the situation arose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Mason I reiterate the point that Senator Missen made to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). He referred to the extent that use or enjoyment has been affected.
—But acquisition is not that thing. You either acquire it or you do not.
—No, you do not either acquire something or not. It is possible that a government could take an action which could very much affect the way one uses or has access to one's property.
—But, Senator, you do not call it acquisition.

—Indeed, the Commonwealth may not call it acquisition. It may acquire it or it may stop one using it or getting access to it, in which case the Government ought to face the fact that its actions are no different in effect from acquisition. Under these circumstances a court would determine that. I refer to Senator Missen's comment in response to Senator Evans when he said: ' A little or a lot?'. The court determines whether it is a little compensation or a lot of compensation under those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (10) and (11) take up an amendment that we moved earlier which seeks replacement of the High Court by the Federal Court. In this case there is no choice. In sub-clause (4) of clause 16 application has to be made to the High Court requesting the Court to make a declaration on the operation of the Act or on the regulations in relation to an acquisition of property. There is no alternative. We want to replace the High Court with the Federal Court, again recognising that there is always a right of appeal to the High Court. So replacing the High Court with the Federal Court does not delete the High Court from the operations of the Act. However, this is a situation in which there could be a large number of applications to the Court by individuals. Without doubt a number of them would go to the High Court because some constitutional issue could be involved or an appeal may be necessary. It seems quite unreasonable, the High Court having made a decision on a matter, that all subsequent cases that might claim to be of a kind should go to the High Court. It would be quite possible for the Federal Court to implement decisions of the High Court.
