Clause 17-Compensation

9. This clause sets out the procedures relating to the determination of any compensation that might be payable for land acquired under the Act or under regulations made pursuant to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. 10. 11. However, in cases of disputed claims for $5 million or more, the Governor- General shall establish a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into and report on the compensation payable. Although the Committee believes that the Report of the Commission of Inquiry would be admissible as evidence in any Federal Court action taken under this clause, the Committee is concerned that the Report may otherwise not be publicly available, either through tabling in Parliament or release to the claimant. 12. The Committee draws attention to the difference in treatment accorded disputed claims which fall either side of the $5 million. TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills for bringing forward its report on this Bill, as indeed, on all others. It is a useful document because it draws attention to some points that need to be answered. In relation to the Committee's report, as with the original amendment moved by the Opposition, insufficient account has been taken of the context in which these compensation provisions are written. I repeat, as I said earlier, that we are dealing with a situation in which acquisition would not be the normally perferred mode of operation of the Commonwealth. To the extent that the Commonwealth wanted to control the management of the land area in question by means of acquisition, it would not do so by acting under this Bill. It would use some other means, notably the Lands Acquisition Act. This Bill only has these provisions in order to cope with the contingency that what it does by way of prohibition of dam building or anything else might just be construed by a court as amounting to an acquisition and, as such, demanding the payment of just terms by virtue of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: I hasten to add that it is highly unlikely that a court would so construe any of this prohibitory activity by the Commonwealth. There are many cases which indicate that a government can engage in all sorts of zoning regulations, prohibitory licensing regulations and so on, without that amounting to an acquisition of the proprietary interest in question, but there is a doubt about it. There are American cases and other exotic cases suggesting that it might amount to an acquisition and, in order to avoid the whole edifice tumbling down in the event that it did have to be construed as an acquisition because of the absence of provisions for just terms, this procedure is built in for the identification of just terms in the unlikely event that something was construed as an acquisition.

I know that that sounds very technical. But it is the only context in which we are here talking about compensation and acquisition. Senator Martin was quite right in saying that the Government would normally be expected to have regard to other considerations-negotiations, consultations and so on-if it comes simply to the business of compensating a State for the effect of Commonwealth action in inhibiting what the State would otherwise like to do. All of those things can occur outside the context of an acquisition exercise. So that is the context in which this provision is contained in the Bill. It is made particularly clear by the vesting of the jurisdiction in respect of these matters in the High Court, which is one of the matters dealt with by the Opposition's amendments. The High Court is given original jurisdiction because we are talking about the curious case of something being construed as an acquisition within the meaning of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution; in other words, a 'constitutional' acquisition is involved and, as such, is something that will ultimately fall for determination by the High Court. Rather than again requiring litigants to wend their weary way up through the court system in order to have this matter determined once and for all by the High Court, since it raises a question of interpretation of the Constitution, we are proposing simply to vest that jurisdiction directly, in the first instance, in the High Court.

It may be that experience of the operation of this legislation will indicate that a number of these claims are made over time and that it would suit the convenience of litigants to have access to some other tier of courts in the system, rather than having to go to the High Court in the first instance. Again, I say that we will take into account the way that this system works and will do our best to accommodate any such experience that shows up. Certainly, in the first likely area of application of this legislation, namely, South West Tasmania, I do not believe anyone is in any doubt but that the High Court is the court that will be involved in the first instance. So there is plenty of time to modify the Act in subsequent amendments, should that prove necessary. But there is a genuine coherent rationale for the High Court being vested with this jurisdiction.

The procedure will have to be looked at in light of the context we are talking about. In involves a highly unusual case. Of course, the distinction between $5m minus and $5m plus is an arbitrary one, but no more so than the usual demarcation between various jurisdictions when some monetary element is involved . There is an element of arbitrariness in any figure that one may choose. I suppose that $5m seems a lot more to honourable senators on this side of the chamber than it does to those on the other side. We could argue about that. But I suggest it is not an unreasonable ground for distinction.

The reason for a special procedure involving a commission of inquiry in respect of claims of more than $5m is the likelihood, as Senator Martin has acknowledged I said in my reply to the second reading debate, that monetary aspects relevant to what compensation is fair and just will in most cases need detailed investigation. They will not involve the ordinary acquisition of land for the purpose of building an aerodrome. They will involve odd cases such as South West Tasmania or matters of that kind. It will be necessary in these sorts of situations to have flexible procedures that can deal with wide-ranging economic arguments about the effect of the Bill. The solutions that might be appropriate by way of compensation in those cases could include, for example, conditional grants, under section 96 of the Constitution to be made by the Commonwealth as part of some development package. Such measures, although they would, constitutionally speaking, constitute an appropriate and effective form of just terms within the meaning of the constitution, would not necessarily be appropriate for judicial determination in the first instance. That is the reason for this commission of inquiry concept being established.

Finally, with regard to some of the procedural aspects that were mentioned in relation to the Commission of Inquiry, Senator Walters raised the question about whether it made any sense for the Governor-General not having to take any notice of the Commission of Inquiry report. I make the point that if the Governor- General-that is, the Commonwealth Government of the day-does not take any notice of the Commission of Inquiry report, it is always open to the aggrieved individual or State to appeal directly to the Federal Court. As to the question raised by Senator Missen about the obligatory tabling of the report, I suggest to him that although in a sense it might be an improvement in the Bill to put the matter clearly beyond doubt it is surely implicit, if not explicit, in the operation of the Bill. For example, clause 17 (14) (c) states that if the person considers that the compensation determined by the Governor-General pursuant to sub-clause (12) in respect of the acquisition is not fair and just then he may apply to the Federal Court for determination of the matter. How on earth could the person make that decision unless there was an implied obligation for the Commission of inquiry's report and so on to be made available to him via the determination of the Governor-General? So, although I can see the point that is being made, I do not believe it is so significant or so necessary for the proper and just working of these provisions that an amendment is necessary at this stage. Again, should a machinery amendment prove to be necessary, of course, that is one of the tidy-up things that we would be prepared to contemplate. But there is not so obviously or starkly a defect on the face of the Bill that in my belief and the Government's belief demands an amendment of this kind.

Mr LOWE (Franklin-Premier):Mr Speaker, I wish to make a ministerial statement. The park encompasses the catchment area of the Franklin and Olga Rivers and the lower part of the Gordon River. In addition, the proclamation provides for the extension of the South West National Park to include the catchment area of the Davey River.

It will be recalled that in July 1980 the Government made a decision on a comprehensive range of future power development and related matters. This development included a major hydro-electric power scheme-the Gordon above Olga scheme-and establishment of a national park of world significance embracing the catchment area of the Franklin River.

At that time I made it clear that it was the Government's desire to obtain approval for its power development scheme before action was taken to proclaim the Wild River National Park. It was the expectation of the Government that at worst the legislation would be passed by Parliament by the end of December 1980. As members will be aware, that legislation was still the subject of disagreement between the two Houses at the end of 1980. That session of Parliament has continued to the present time with the matter remaining unresolved.

As a result of the latest conference of managers of both Houses held this morning, it is quite clear that major disagreement remains on this matter in respect of values, philosophy and interpretation with regard to various points of detail.

It was the Government's initial intention, prior to the development of the current impasse with the Legislative Council, not to proclaim the Wild River National Park until such time as the matter of future power development was finalised. However, the circumstances of disagreement which I have described have compelled the Government to pursue a different course of action.

Continuing inaction in regard to proclamation of the national park may have led some to doubt the Government's determination to save the Franklin River whilst simultaneously ensuring that our energy future is also adequately protected. So that the Government's position can be made quite clear, it has therefore decided that this national park should be proclaimed in the south-west of the State without further delay. I will today be writing to the Prime Minister asking him to amend the Australian Government's submission for World Heritage listing of the South West National Park to include the areas covered by today's proclamation.

Approval of the power scheme is a matter for Parliament. Approval of the national park and its boundaries is a matter for government decision, and that decision has now been formalised. Construction of the next power development scheme can proceed as soon as Parliament approves the legislation. The Government awaits that approval with great anxiety, having regard to the consequences of further prolonged deferral of a decision on this vital matter.

In short, my Government's judgment in relation to the next major power development was taken within the context of a package of policy initiatives, the principal thrust of which was a continuing all-hydro power development aimed at enhancing the social and economic well-being of the State, together with the protection of certain unique wilderness areas. My Government does not retreat from these important policy commitments, as evidenced by today's proclamation.

—You have a perfect right to raise the matter during the third reading debate. I allowed, in order to expedite proceedings, Senator Missen to raise a matter which was not relevant to the remaining clauses of the Bill. You can speak to the third reading if you so wish.
—Mr Chairman, I would like to know why you did not rule him out of order.
—I am ruling you out of order now. You may speak to the remaining clauses of the Bill.

—I am speaking to clause 18. Mr Chairman, I hope you recognise the fact that I have not spoken on more than one occasion on any of the clauses. I refer the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to clause 18 of the Bill which relates to the delegation of authority by the Minister. That clause indicates that the Minister may delegate his authority to a person in respect of any of the powers that he has under clauses 9, 10 or 11 of the Bill. These clauses are vital clauses which deal with the methods of ensuring the implementation of this legislation in respect of identified properties. It would be a matter of concern if, for example, the Minister were to delegate his powers to a designated person who would be the ipso facto major domo of the World Heritage Committee in Australia. For example, he could delegate his power to a person such as Professor Bellamy. The Government could get him out here especially and he could be the person to whom delegated power could be given under this provision. As the matters are so important I would like the Minister not to delegate his power in respect of those matters, especially when the identified properties are properties relating to a State. I wonder whether the Minister would respond by saying that the person he represents in this chamber does not intend to delegate the authority which he has under clauses 9, 10 and 11 of the Bill.

—The powers of delegation under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill are wide but not unusually wide. Whether they are being exercised by an ipso facto major domo or by anyone else they are still subject to challenge under the enforcement provisions of clauses 13 and 14 of the Bill; that is to say, as to the prohibitions, consents and so on. In clause 13 there is provision for redress through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, no matter who exercises delegation.
—Would the Minister's decisions be subject to that?
—Certainly, the Minister's decisions, too; there is no doubt about that. Not only the delegator but also the delegatee would have their decisions challengeable under these provisions.
—With respect, that statement does not meet the point that I made. On matters of such grave importance it is unusual for the Minister to delegate power.
—We can stand here all night saying: 'It is. It is not'. 'It is. It is not'.
—To whom is it envisaged the power would be delegated?

—On some big decisions, for example, 'thou shall not construct a dam', it would be highly unlikely that the Minister would delegate his power. On small decisions, for example, 'thou shall not knock down a bush larger than two metres high', one could reasonably delegate to someone down the line within the Department. There will be big decisions and little decisions. The prospect is that the big decisions would be retained by the Minister and the little ones would be farmed out. In either event they are all challengeable.
—Within the Department?
—One would expect so, yes. That is as I read the clause-in the normal way, down the line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose the third reading of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. I do so because I believe that the Parliament of the Commonwealth has done a disservice to the community; it has done a disservice to the Constitution. Senator Missen, prior to the finalisation of the Committee stage, raised an issue about which I took some exception because he had done so in order to clothe what has been done tonight with some sort of democratic principle. That he cannot do. I attempted to answer Senator Missen in the Committee stage and was invited by the Chairman of Committees to do so on the third reading.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, particularly clause 6, enables the Commonwealth to make a proclamation in relation to identified property that is in a State and is property to which one or more of the paragraphs in clause 6 apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate will hold up the whole Senate.

—Senator Chipp is leaving the chamber after having described me as a mental defective. One is not a judge in one's own case but fortunately Senator Chipp is not one of my electors. This measure enables the Commonwealth, without reference to the Parliament of any State, to nominate a property for listing by the World Heritage Committee. Under those circumstances not only the persons of the State have no say in the matter but also citizens of the Commonwealth have no say in that matter other than by disallowance of the proclamation. In the instant case of South West Tasmania no one can say that that nomination went forward to the World Heritage Committee and was listed with the approval of the Tasmanian Parliament. That is the sort of implication that was made by Senator Missen, and it is totally unfair for him to make that implication because it is just not so. The Premier of the day put forward the nomination. He did in fact, as has been indicated, report it to Parliament, but the Parliament did not vote on that nomination. To be fair, the Premier of the day put forward the nomination when legislation such as this was not on the statute books and when he was prepared to build a dam, namely the Gordon above Olga, within that South West Tasmania nominated area. That is something that has not come out in the debate so far.
—Why are you raising it now? Why didn't you raise it at the proper time so I could get a chance to answer it?

—The honourable senator can answer afterwards. The Premier of the day put forward the nomination for inclusion on the World Heritage List when he knew that his policy was for the building of the Gordon above Olga dam, which is in the nominated area, the identified area. It is pure cant and hypocrisy to suggest that his action-that is to say, the action of the State premier in nominating this particular area-should be used as a trigger for the operations of this Bill. Furthermore, I remind the Senate that Article 34 (b) of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, which is set out in the Schedule to the Bill, provides:

SPEECH.PARA: with regard to the provisions of this convention, the implementation of which comes under the legal jurisdiction of individual constituent States, countries, provinces or cantons that are not obliged by the constitutional system of the federation to take legislative measures, the federal government shall inform the competent authorities of such States, countries, provinces or cantons of the said provisions, with its recommendations for their adoption.

The nomination of this area proceeded not with the approval of the State Government but in fact with its active disapproval. By a telex dated 28 June 1982 the Premier of Tasmania requested that the nomination be withdrawn and subsequently by letter of 16 August 1982 he renewed the request but the nomination was not withdrawn. I point out to the Senate that, in respect of the five nominated areas, South West Tasmania is the only one which has not in effect met with the approval of the particular State concerned. Yet we have the Commonwealth Government proceeding inexorably with its legal and political moves -at great cost, might I add-to the democratic principles of subsidiarity and to democracy in this nation.

I am concerned that what the Senate has done tonight will react against this federation. I believe that even if the High Court of Australia considers that the legislation that we have passed is not properly based, the issue will not stop there. The Tasmanian Wilderness Society has announced already that, irrespective of what we do or what the High Court does, there is an eight-year program to stop power development in the area-in other words, to overthrow and override the democratic decisions that have been taken by the groups within the parliamentary system which have the responsibility and the information to take those decisions. Those people-namely, members of the Wilderness Society and others-have declared their intention. They will attempt to impose their will on the rest of us-I include everybody in this chamber and on the High Court- irrespective of democracy and civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you include me?
—Yes, I include the honourable senator. All right, we can differ on various-
—How can they impose their will on the High Court?

—They can do so by the blockade tactics they have thrown up only over the last six months. If those blockade tactics and the tactics of those who have an imbalanced attitude on this issue are disapproved of, honourable senators should say that they disapprove of them and let the law take its course. But let me say that I will remember those who have said that those tactics are not appropriate. Can I take it that Government members would say that if this measure fails in the High Court that should be the end of the matter? Am I clear on that-that that should be the end of the matter? If the High Court rules as invalid any measures taken under this legislation do honourable senators opposite accept that that is where the situation lies and that is where it ends? I take it by the silence of Government members-
—I am going to be quite happy with that. I trust the High Court to come down with the right decisions.

—I just remind the Senate of what has been said by Mr Bob Brown of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society. In an announcement broadcast last week by the Australian Broadcasting Commission he said that no matter what happened in the High Court or in the Parliament the development will not proceed . I ask the Senate to have regard to that. Finally, I ask the Senate to ensure that that sort of undemocratic approach is not countenanced so that democracy will prevail in the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Harradine, I attempted to answer certain allegations that were raised by Senator Missen and the Chairman of Committees thought it would be more appropriate to answer the allegations at the third reading stage. I want to answer those allegations by Senator Missen who challenged my remark about the process by which this matter in relation to the listing proceeded through Cabinet, Caucus and the Parliament. Honourable senators may recall that my remark was that I believed the process lacked a certain openness and honesty within government. In fact, on reading the extract of the House of Assembly Hansard of 30 April 1981, which my colleague had incorporated in Hansard, we note that former Premier Lowe made a ministerial statement in the Tasmanian House of Assembly in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to inform the House that at a special meeting of the Executive Council held earlier this afternoon, the establishment of a wild river national park was proclaimed.
Later in the statement, he said:

It was the Government's initial intention, prior to the development of the current impasse with the Legislative Council, not to proclaim the Wild River National Park until such time as the matter of future power development was finalised. However, the circumstances of disagreement which I have described have compelled the Government to pursue a different course of action.
I think that the only difference in the situation is that former Premier Lowe issued a ministerial statement after the event.
